queries.company_overview:
What it does: Arm Holdings plc designs and licenses CPU, GPU, and system IP based on the Arm architecture, monetizing through up-front licenses and ongoing per-chip royalties across smartphones, data center, automotive, PC, and IoT. It also offers compute subsystem platforms (CSS), developer tools, and support services to accelerate customer chip development.
Main business units / segments:
- Single reportable segment; revenue reported by streams and end markets
- License and other (IP licenses, support, and services)
- Royalty (per-chip royalties from Arm-based silicon)
- Target end markets: Client/mobile & PC; Infrastructure/data center; Automotive; IoT/embedded
- Compute Subsystems (CSS) platforms to accelerate customer chip development
High-level financials: FY2025 (year ended 2025-03-31) revenue $4.007B; FY2025 net income $792M; market capitalization $167.0B as of 2025-11-05.
Competitive positioning: Arm competes against x86 ecosystems (Intel, AMD) in servers and PCs, and against the RISC-V ecosystem (e.g., SiFive and broader open-source implementations) across embedded and edge. It remains the default architecture in smartphones and is gaining share in cloud servers and AI PCs via partners’ Arm-based designs; advantages include power efficiency, broad IP portfolio, and a large developer ecosystem.
Recent major news:
- 2025-07-30 Arm reports Q1 FY2026 results: revenue $1.053B, GAAP net income $130M
- 2025-05-07 Arm reports FY2025 results: revenue $4.01B, first $1B quarter, GAAP EPS $0.75
- 2025-04-16 Cadence to acquire Arm’s Artisan foundation IP business (definitive agreement)
- 2025-06-04 Arm unveils Zena CSS for automotive to accelerate AI-enabled vehicle compute
- 2025-01-14 Arm appoints Eric Hayes as EVP of Operations

Arm expected timeline for next-generatio.query: Arm expected timeline for next-generation Armv10 CPU architecture public disclosure
Arm expected timeline for next-generatio.answer: Arm has not announced Armv10 or provided any public disclosure timeline. Official materials position Armv9 as the platform for the next decade, with partners supported “well into the 2030s,” and Arm continues to roll out Armv9.x updates through 2025—indicating a near‑term Armv10 reveal is unlikely.

search_results.title: Armv9: The Future of Specialized Compute
search_results.snippet: Arm frames Armv9 as the architecture powering the next 300 billion chips and supporting the ecosystem well into the 2030s; there is no mention of Armv10 or any timeline for its disclosure, implying continued Armv9.x evolution rather than a near-term Armv10 announcement.

search_results.title: Arm CPU Architecture
search_results.snippet: Arm’s CPU architecture page lists Armv9-A (and Armv8-A) as the latest A-profile versions; it contains no public reference to an Armv10 specification or disclosure date, indicating Arm’s current public roadmap remains centered on Armv9.

search_results.title: AArch64 - Wikipedia
search_results.snippet: The AArch64 page documents successive Armv9.x-A releases (e.g., Armv9.5-A in 2023, Armv9.6-A in 2024, Armv9.7-A in 2025), showing ongoing feature additions within Armv9 and no announced Armv10—supporting that Arm is still iterating v9 rather than disclosing v10.

Arm updated forecast for smartphone roya.query: Arm updated forecast for smartphone royalty growth from Armv9 and CSS adoption
Arm updated forecast for smartphone roya.answer: Arm updated its outlook to say royalty growth will be in the high-teens for FY25, driven by rising Armv9 mix and the initial ramp of CSS-based designs, with smartphone royalties expected to keep outpacing handset unit growth. Recent results showed smartphone royalty growth of ~40% YoY in Q2 and Q3 and about 30% in Q4 as v9 penetration and early CSS shipments (e.g., MediaTek Dimensity 9400) lifted per-device royalty rates.

search_results.title: Arm Q2: V9 & CSS Transform Growth Model - Creative Strategies
search_results.snippet: Arm said smartphone royalties grew ~40% YoY despite only ~4% unit growth, reflecting higher v9-based royalty rates and CSS ramp. Management projected high-teens royalty growth for the full year, with the mix shift to Armv9 and early CSS deployments cited as key drivers of continued outperformance in smartphones.

search_results.title: Arm Achieves Record Q2 Results
search_results.snippet: Arm reported royalty revenue up 23% YoY, noting smartphone royalties rose about 40% YoY as Armv9 reached roughly 25% of royalty revenue. It also highlighted that CSS-based products began to ship (e.g., Microsoft Cobalt, Google Axion, MediaTek Dimensity 9400), supporting higher per-device royalty capture and sustained smartphone royalty growth.

search_results.title: Arm Q4 FY 2025: Record Revenue as Armv9 and CSS Ramp Up - Futurum Group
search_results.snippet: Arm said Q4 royalty revenue rose 18% YoY, with smartphone royalties up ~30% YoY despite flat handset units, as v9’s higher royalty rate and CSS adoption expanded value per device. Management noted Armv9 exceeded 30% of royalty revenue and expects further uplift as second-generation CSS arrives, reinforcing the smartphone royalty growth outlook.

Arm FY2026 revenue guidance midpoint and.query: Arm FY2026 revenue guidance midpoint and underlying license and royalty mix assumptions
Arm FY2026 revenue guidance midpoint and.answer: Arm did not issue formal full-year FY2026 revenue guidance, so there is no midpoint. Management cited tariff and macro uncertainty and only offered directional commentary: a softer H1 followed by 10–15% sequential revenue growth in H2, implying roughly ~20% FY2026 revenue growth. The underlying mix assumptions emphasize royalties leading growth (mid‑teens to ~20%+ annually from Armv9/CSS uplift) while licensing grows mid‑single digits and remains more volatile due to the timing of large deals.

search_results.title: ARM Earnings: Tariffs Shut Down 2026 Guidance, Revenue Growth Still Strong
search_results.snippet: Morningstar reports Arm shut down FY2026 guidance due to tariff uncertainty; management suggested a softer first half and 10–15% sequential revenue growth in the second half, implying around 20% FY2026 revenue growth, with royalty growth underpinned by higher royalty rates and share gains.

search_results.title: Arm says it isn't worried by tariffs, but no FY26 guidance
search_results.snippet: The Register notes Arm declined to provide full-year FY’26 guidance; CFO Jason Child guided Q1 FY26 revenue to $1.0–$1.1B and indicated royalties would be flattish into Q2 before 10–15% sequential growth in the back half, highlighting near‑term license/royalty dynamics without a full‑year midpoint.

search_results.title: Transcript (Q&A): Arm Business Briefing
search_results.snippet: Arm IR outlined long‑term mix assumptions: royalty revenue growth in the high‑teens to ~20% range per year and licensing growth in the mid‑single digits, implying royalties drive the majority of growth—key context for underlying license/royalty mix assumptions relevant to FY2026.

Arm planned CSS roadmap milestones for d.query: Arm planned CSS roadmap milestones for data center, PC, and automotive through FY2026
Arm planned CSS roadmap milestones for d.answer: Arm’s CSS roadmap through FY2026 spans three pillars: in data center, Arm extended Neoverse CSS in Feb 2024 with N3 and the first V‑series CSS (V3), laying the platform for next‑gen hyperscale CPUs. For PCs/Client, Arm launched CSS for Client in May–June 2024 with Armv9.2 Cortex‑X925/A725, DSU‑120 up to 14 cores, and 3nm physical implementations to enable AI PCs and Android SoCs. In automotive, Arm introduced Zena CSS in June 2025, a pre‑integrated AE‑based subsystem that shortens silicon timelines by up to 12 months and targets ADAS/IVI, with broader OEM adoption expected into FY2026.

search_results.title: Enabling the AI Infrastructure on Arm
search_results.snippet: Arm extended its Neoverse CSS roadmap for data centers in Feb 2024, adding Neoverse CSS N3 (≈20% perf/watt over N2) and the first V‑series Neoverse CSS V3 (≈50% perf/socket uplift), alongside an expanded Arm Total Design ecosystem and chiplet support—setting the data‑center CSS milestones that partners will carry into FY2026 deployments.

search_results.title: Arm CSS for Client: The Compute Platform for AI-powered Consumer Experiences
search_results.snippet: Arm’s CSS for Client (announced May–June 2024) packages an Armv9.2 CPU cluster (Cortex‑X925, Cortex‑A725, Cortex‑A520), updated DSU and CoreLink, and production‑ready 3nm physical implementations, enabling rapid AI PC and Android SoC roadmaps with up to 14 cores—key PC milestones on the CSS plan through FY2026.

search_results.title: Automakers Can Launch AI-Defined Vehicles a Full Year Sooner – Powered by Arm Zena CSS
search_results.snippet: In June 2025 Arm unveiled Zena CSS, a standardized, pre‑integrated automotive compute subsystem (with safety and security islands) that reduces silicon development by up to 12 months and cuts engineering effort—marking the automotive CSS milestone that Arm and OEMs plan to scale into FY2026 for ADAS, IVI, and broader AI‑defined vehicle use cases.

Arm near-term actions to accelerate Wind.query: Arm near-term actions to accelerate Windows on Arm PC design wins with OEMs
Arm near-term actions to accelerate Wind.answer: Arm’s near-term push centers on making it faster and lower-risk for OEMs to ship Windows on Arm PCs. It launched production-ready Compute Subsystems for Client (CSS) that bundle Armv9.2 CPU clusters and GPUs on 3nm to shorten partners’ SoC design cycles for laptops/PCs. In parallel, Arm and Microsoft are co-engineering the WoA ecosystem—declaring the platform “ready” for OEMs—while Microsoft’s Prism emulator, Arm64EC, and App Assure Arm Advisory reduce app-compatibility risk and speed OEM commercialization.

search_results.title: Arm Compute Subsystems (CSS) for Client
search_results.snippet: Arm’s CSS for Client packages next‑gen Armv9.2 CPUs (Cortex‑X925/A725/A520), Immortalis GPUs, CoreLink system IP, and production‑ready 3nm physical implementations to accelerate partners’ SoC development for AI‑enhanced laptops and PCs. By providing a hardened, scalable client compute foundation, Arm reduces OEM time‑to‑market and risk for Windows on Arm PC design wins.

search_results.title: How Arm and Microsoft are Building the Future of Laptop Computing
search_results.snippet: Arm says Windows on Arm is now “ready for OEMs, developers and Windows users,” highlighting deep co‑engineering with Microsoft to deliver performance, efficiency, and new AI experiences. The companies are driving Arm‑native apps and optimizing edge‑AI workloads—explicitly positioning WoA devices for OEM adoption and urging the ecosystem to “jump in.”

search_results.title: Windows on Arm documentation
search_results.snippet: Microsoft details near‑term enablers that de‑risk OEM WoA launches: Windows 11 runs many x86/x64 apps via the new Prism emulator, while Arm‑native tooling and Arm64EC enable incremental porting for top performance. App Assure’s Arm Advisory Service and Arm‑ready developer workflows further smooth OEM productization and software readiness for Windows on Arm PCs.

Arm latest guidance on royalty rate upli.query: Arm latest guidance on royalty rate uplift from CSS versus baseline Armv9 cores
Arm latest guidance on royalty rate upli.answer: Recent management commentary and analyst summaries indicate Arm’s Compute Subsystems (CSS) carry roughly double the royalty rate versus baseline Armv9 core implementations. Current guidance and third-party analysis peg Armv9 core royalties around ~5%, while CSS designs are ~10% or higher, with next-gen CSS expected to exceed that level.

search_results.title: ARM Earnings Meet Guidance But Narrative Is Shifting and Questions Loom
search_results.snippet: Morningstar reports that CSS designs carry royalty rates of 10% or higher, versus roughly 5% for Armv9 and about 2.5–3% for Armv8, underscoring a substantial uplift for CSS over baseline v9 cores and indicating room for further increases as CSS adoption expands.

search_results.title: BofA ups Arm Holdings shares target, expects growth from v9 architecture
search_results.snippet: Bank of America’s note suggests the v9 transition can double or lift royalty rates to roughly 4–5%, while Arm’s complete compute solution (CSS) can quadruple or raise rates to about 8–10%, implying CSS carries roughly 2x the rate of baseline v9 cores.

search_results.title: Arm Q2: V9 & CSS Transform Growth Model
search_results.snippet: Industry analysis highlights that CSS licenses can command 2x+ royalty premiums relative to standard v9 core licensing; coupled with strong v9 adoption, CSS materially lifts blended royalty rates and supports multi-year royalty growth beyond unit trends.

Arm expected RPO conversion percentages.query: Arm expected RPO conversion percentages by quarter for the next four quarters
Arm expected RPO conversion percentages.answer: Arm does not disclose RPO conversion by individual quarter. Instead, management guides to time buckets: most recently, Arm said about 25% of RPO is expected to convert to revenue over the next 12 months and about 19% over months 13–24 (May 2025). Earlier disclosures referenced roughly 28% within 12 months (late 2023/early 2024), with the remainder beyond. No quarter-by-quarter split for the next four quarters is published.

search_results.title: ARM delivers soft guidance offsetting better-than-expected Q4 results; shares fall
search_results.snippet: Following fiscal Q4 results, Arm reported remaining performance obligations (RPO) of $2.23B and stated it expects to recognize approximately 25% of RPO as revenue over the next 12 months, 19% over the subsequent 13–24 months, with the balance thereafter. The disclosure provides timing buckets rather than a quarter-by-quarter breakdown.

search_results.title: ARM Q2 2024 Earnings Call Transcript
search_results.snippet: In Q&A, management and analysts reference Arm’s RPO timing, noting guidance that about 28% of RPO is expected to be recognized over the next 12 months. This frames RPO conversion in annual buckets, not by specific quarter phasing.

search_results.title: ARM rallies 25% following impressive beat and raise quarter
search_results.snippet: Coverage of Arm’s results notes RPO of ~$2.43B and cites management’s expectation to recognize approximately 28% of RPO over the next 12 months and ~26% over months 13–24, with the remainder later. The commentary reflects timing buckets rather than quarter-by-quarter conversion.

Arm current status of Apple architectura.query: Arm current status of Apple architectural license renewal timing and revenue visibility
Arm current status of Apple architectura.answer: Arm disclosed in its Sept. 2023 IPO filing that Apple signed a new long‑term agreement extending Apple’s access to Arm architecture beyond 2040, implying the renewal was executed in late Aug–early Sept. 2023. Revenue visibility from Apple remains modest: reports indicate Apple pays Arm less than $0.30 per chip and contributes under 5% of Arm’s annual revenue, suggesting long‑term continuity but limited upside from Apple royalties.

search_results.title: Apple inks new long-term deal with Arm for chip technology - filing
search_results.snippet: Arm’s IPO filing revealed a new long‑term agreement with Apple that extends beyond 2040, maintaining Apple’s access to Arm architecture. The deal, not in prior filings, was signed shortly before Sept. 5, 2023, clarifying renewal timing and providing multi‑decade continuity, though financial terms were not disclosed.

search_results.title: Report: Apple Pays Less Than 30 Cents in Royalties to Arm Per Chip
search_results.snippet: The Information reports Apple pays Arm under $0.30 per chip and represents less than 5% of Arm’s annual revenue—the lowest royalty rate among Arm’s smartphone customers. The piece adds Apple’s current agreement, signed in Sept. 2023, extends beyond 2040, implying long‑term continuity but modest revenue visibility from Apple.

search_results.title: Apple makes up less than 5% of Arm’s revenue, and Arm can’t do anything about it
search_results.snippet: Apple accounts for under 5% of Arm’s sales and pays less than $0.30 per device; attempts by SoftBank to raise Apple’s fees were unsuccessful, with earlier terms reportedly running through 2028. While Apple has explored RISC‑V, the current multi‑decade Arm agreement secures access to Arm IP but limits royalty upside for Arm.

Arm initiatives to increase developer to.query: Arm initiatives to increase developer tooling performance for AI workloads on Arm
Arm initiatives to increase developer to.answer: Arm’s key initiative is Arm Kleidi, a suite of open‑source AI acceleration libraries integrated directly into major frameworks like PyTorch and ExecuTorch so developers get automatic, out‑of‑the‑box performance gains on Arm CPUs across cloud and edge. This builds on the Arm Compute Library and upstream contributions, with Arm reporting substantial speedups (for example, 2.5x faster time‑to‑first‑token on AWS Graviton and ~20% prefill gains on mobile for quantized Llama with ExecuTorch+KleidiAI), plus learning paths and resources to simplify adoption.

search_results.title: Arm Accelerates AI From Cloud to Edge With New PyTorch and ExecuTorch Integrations to Deliver Immediate Performance Improvements for Developers
search_results.snippet: Arm announces Kleidi integrations with PyTorch and ExecuTorch that embed Arm‑optimized kernels directly into these frameworks, giving developers immediate AI performance improvements on Arm CPUs from cloud to edge without extra integration work; measured gains include 2.5x faster time‑to‑first‑token on AWS Graviton4 and 1.35–2x inference speedups on Hugging Face workloads, with ongoing focus on quantization and forward‑compatible enhancements.

search_results.title: Kleidi – Software-Level AI Acceleration
search_results.snippet: Arm Kleidi is an open‑source, framework‑integrated acceleration initiative that delivers out‑of‑the‑box AI performance on Arm CPUs via technologies like the Arm Compute Library and KleidiAI; Arm highlights PyTorch speedups (e.g., up to 2.2x on BERT‑Large and large uplifts on Llama), planned and active ExecuTorch enablement, optimizations for XNNPACK and other frameworks, and developer resources to simplify building performant AI on Arm.

search_results.title: Unleashing the Power of AI on Mobile: LLM Inference for Llama 3.2 Quantized Models with ExecuTorch and KleidiAI
search_results.snippet: PyTorch and Arm detail how KleidiAI integrates into ExecuTorch via XNNPACK to accelerate on‑device AI on Arm Cortex‑A CPUs; quantized Llama 3.2 models see up to 20% faster prefill on Arm v9 with I8MM and achieve >350 tokens/s prefill and >40 tokens/s decode on a Samsung S24+, demonstrating practical, low‑effort performance gains for developers adopting Arm’s framework‑level optimizations.

Arm near-term strategy to deepen partner.query: Arm near-term strategy to deepen partnerships with hyperscalers for custom silicon
Arm near-term strategy to deepen partner.answer: Arm’s near-term strategy is to co-develop and accelerate hyperscalers’ custom Arm-based silicon using Neoverse Compute Subsystems (CSS) and the Arm Total Design ecosystem, reducing time-to-silicon and costs. The company is pursuing more direct OEM/customization deals with cloud providers as AI drives demand for workload-optimized chips, with active programs like AWS Graviton, Google Axion, and Microsoft’s Cobalt CPUs.

search_results.title: Half of the Compute Shipped to Top Hyperscalers in 2025 will be Arm-based
search_results.snippet: Arm says top hyperscalers (AWS, Google Cloud, Microsoft Azure) are using Arm to build their own custom CPUs to optimize power and TCO, enabled by Neoverse to shape silicon roadmaps and create tailored AI silicon. It highlights Arm-based cloud chipsets like AWS Graviton, Google Axion, and Microsoft Cobalt as evidence of deeper, custom silicon partnerships.

search_results.title: Arm looks to cut more OEM deals as hyperscaler demand grows—Thanks, NVIDIA?
search_results.snippet: CEO Rene Haas told investors Arm expects up to 50% of new hyperscaler server chips this year to be Arm-based and plans to strike more direct OEM/customization deals. He said hyperscalers are standardizing on Arm and accelerating relationships as they design unique, workload-specific silicon across blades, racks, and systems, especially for AI.

search_results.title: Arm announces 3rd Gen Neoverse Compute Subsystems blueprints and expanded design ecosystem
search_results.snippet: Arm expanded Neoverse CSS (N3, V3) and its Arm Total Design ecosystem to cut NRE and speed delivery of customized data center silicon for cloud and AI. The company cites strong adoption by hyperscalers, with Microsoft’s Cobalt CPUs as a CSS-based example—underscoring Arm’s strategy to deepen co-development with hyperscalers for custom silicon.

Arm planned release schedule for next Ne.query: Arm planned release schedule for next Neoverse platforms targeting AI inference and training
Arm planned release schedule for next Ne.answer: Arm announced its next Neoverse platforms for AI on Feb 21, 2024: Neoverse CSS V3 (V-series) and CSS N3 (N-series), with IP available to partners for licensing now. Independent analysis expects first processors built on these subsystems to reach production in H2 2025. Arm’s roadmap also shows the follow-on V4/N4 generation (Adonis/Dionysus) with CSS Vega/Ranger, but Arm has not published dates.

search_results.title: Enabling the AI Infrastructure on Arm
search_results.snippet: On Feb 21, 2024, Arm introduced two new Neoverse Compute Subsystems built on 3rd‑generation Neoverse IP—CSS V3 for high performance (claimed +50% performance‑per‑socket over CSS N2) and CSS N3 for efficiency (+20% performance‑per‑watt vs CSS N2). Arm positions these pre‑integrated subsystems to accelerate partners’ time‑to‑market for AI infrastructure across data center workloads, including AI inference.

search_results.title: Arm Neoverse Roadmap Brings CPU Designs, But No Big Fat GPU
search_results.snippet: Arm’s 2024 Neoverse roadmap shows V3 (Poseidon) and N3 (Hermes) cores with CSS packages—Voyager (V3) and Pioneer (N3)—available now, targeting AI inference and some CPU‑side training. Follow‑on platforms V4 ‘Adonis’/CSS ‘Vega’ and N4 ‘Dionysus’/CSS ‘Ranger’ are on the roadmap, but Arm withheld dates, signaling future iterations without a public release timeline.

search_results.title: Arm Adds Compute Subsystem for V3 | TechInsights

Arm current average selling price assump.query: Arm current average selling price assumptions underlying royalty per-chip projections
Arm current average selling price assump.answer: Arm’s per‑chip royalty projections are based on applying a royalty percentage to the chip’s selling price (ASP). Historically the assumed range has been about 1–2% of the chip ASP (with newer Armv9 designs roughly doubling Armv8 rates), so dollar‑per‑chip outcomes scale with the ASP by segment: pennies for low‑ASP MCUs, tens of cents for many phone SoCs (e.g., Apple reportedly pays < $0.30 per chip), and dollars or more on high‑value server/auto chips.

search_results.title: Message from Arm CEO—SoftBank Group Report 2024
search_results.snippet: Arm explains that royalties are related to the selling price of the chip and increase as customers use more or more advanced Arm processors; it adds that Armv9’s typical royalty fee was about double Armv8. This underscores that per‑chip royalty projections depend on the assumed chip ASP and product mix by architecture.

search_results.title: Report: Apple Pays Less Than 30 Cents in Royalties to Arm Per Chip
search_results.snippet: Citing The Information, Apple pays Arm a flat fee of less than $0.30 per chip across devices like iPhone, iPad, and Mac. The figure illustrates the per‑unit magnitude many modelers assume for high‑volume devices and how actual per‑chip royalties can vary by contract versus a simple percent‑of‑ASP approach.

search_results.title: How ARM licenses its IP for production
search_results.snippet: Detailed overview of ARM’s licensing terms notes royalties are typically 1–2% of the selling price of the end chip/SoC (with v8 class a bit higher), i.e., calculated on chip ASP; the rate varies with architecture and configuration, implying per‑chip royalty projections rest on assumed chip ASPs across segments.

search_results.title: Exclusive-MediaTek designs Arm-based chip for Microsoft's AI laptops, say sources
search_results.snippet: Reuters reports MediaTek is developing an Arm-based Windows PC chip for Microsoft’s AI-focused laptops, with launch late next year (late 2025) after Qualcomm’s exclusivity ends. The article also notes Nvidia and AMD are working on Arm designs, and that MediaTek’s PC chip project is separate from its Nvidia collaboration.

search_results.title: MediaTek-NVIDIA Partnership to Bring Windows-on-Arm PCs in 2025
search_results.snippet: Counterpoint says MediaTek and NVIDIA will extend their partnership to Windows-on-Arm PCs, with the first AI PC expected in 2025. Based on its checks, MediaTek is likely to launch a Windows-on-Arm solution in H2 2025, targeting Copilot+ requirements (~45 NPU TOPS), which could catalyze a broader Arm PC wave.

Arm measures to mitigate export control.query: Arm measures to mitigate export control risks impacting China license shipments
Arm measures to mitigate export control.answer: Arm is mitigating export-control risks on China-bound license shipments by tailoring what it licenses and how it delivers it. According to reporting and Arm’s own risk disclosures, the company steers Chinese customers toward alternative, lower‑performance CPU cores that fall below U.S./U.K. HPC export thresholds, and it runs a process to provide ‘optimized’ solutions that meet partners’ performance needs while remaining fully compliant with export rules. This approach lets Arm continue serving China customers without shipping its most restricted Neoverse designs.

search_results.title: U.S., UK export controls hit China's access to Arm's chip designs -FT
search_results.snippet: Reuters reports that Arm, while blocking access to its highest-performance Neoverse designs in China due to U.S./U.K. rules, says it is fully compliant and has a process to deliver optimized, compliant solutions for partners like Alibaba—i.e., tailoring offerings to stay within export thresholds so China license shipments can continue legally.

search_results.title: Arm reveals just how vulnerable it is to trade war with China
search_results.snippet: Summarizing Arm’s IPO filing, The Register notes that export controls trigger licensing needs for top Neoverse cores in China; to mitigate, Arm addresses China demand by licensing other CPU cores that do not exceed HPC export-control performance thresholds—maintaining compliant shipments while serving customers.

search_results.title: Arm shies away from China over US and UK export controls on advanced chips
search_results.snippet: City A.M. cites an Arm spokesperson saying the firm adheres to all export laws and has a process to deliver optimised solutions that remain compliant—indicating Arm adapts its IP and licensing to meet Chinese partners’ needs without breaching U.S./U.K. restrictions, helping mitigate risks to license shipments.

Arm plans to standardize UCIe chiplet in.query: Arm plans to standardize UCIe chiplet interfaces within upcoming CSS offerings
Arm plans to standardize UCIe chiplet in.answer: Yes. Arm’s latest Neoverse Compute Subsystems (CSS), including the new V3 and N3 platforms, explicitly support UCIe for high‑speed die‑to‑die links, signaling a move to standardize chiplet interfaces around UCIe in CSS. Arm’s own specs list UCIe 1.1 support, and independent reports confirm CSS will use the UCIe standard to link chiplets and enable interoperable multi‑die designs.

search_results.title: Neoverse Compute Subsystems V3 (CSS V3)
search_results.snippet: Arm’s official CSS V3 specifications state the subsystem includes high‑speed die‑to‑die links supporting UCIe 1.1 (or custom PHYs), indicating that Arm is aligning upcoming CSS offerings with standardized UCIe chiplet interfaces to enable interoperable multi‑die integration.

search_results.title: Arm targets AI performance with latest Neoverse Compute Subsystems
search_results.snippet: Coverage of Arm’s CSS N3 and CSS V3 launch notes support for the UCIe standard to link chiplets together; alongside PCIe/CXL and HBM support, this confirms that the new CSS offerings will use UCIe for chiplet interconnects, standardizing die‑to‑die links across the platform.

search_results.title: Arm launches new Neoverse compute subsystems built on third-generation V and N-Series designs
search_results.snippet: The announcement of CSS N3 and V3 highlights support for PCIe, CXL and UCIe chiplet standards, showing Arm’s plan to unlock chiplet technology in CSS by adopting UCIe as the standardized die‑to‑die interface for future multi‑chip designs.

Arm strategy to accelerate Android OEM a.query: Arm strategy to accelerate Android OEM adoption of Arm CSS for flagship smartphones
Arm strategy to accelerate Android OEM a.answer: Arm’s strategy is to speed Android OEM adoption by delivering pre-validated Compute Subsystems (CSS) for Client that bundle Armv9.2 CPUs, Immortalis GPU, CoreLink system IP, and production-ready 3nm physical implementations, tuned as Arm’s fastest platform for Android. Paired with the Kleidi AI/CV software libraries and deep collaboration with foundries and silicon partners, CSS shortens time-to-silicon, boosts Android workload and on-device AI performance, and enables faster rollout of flagship smartphones.

search_results.title: Arm CSS for Client: The Compute Platform for AI-powered Consumer Experiences
search_results.snippet: Arm positions CSS for Client as a pre-validated compute foundation for AI smartphones that unites Armv9.2 CPUs (Cortex‑X925/A725/A520), Immortalis‑G925 GPU, CoreLink system IP, and production-ready 3nm physical implementations. Tuned as Arm’s fastest platform for Android, it targets first‑gen 3nm Android SoCs with roughly 30%+ compute/graphics gains, 59% faster AI inference, faster LLM response, and a shorter path to silicon—accelerating flagship launches.

search_results.title: Arm answers AI's push into PCs, smartphones with CSS for Client
search_results.snippet: Coverage of the launch explains CSS for Client combines Armv9.2 cores (Cortex‑X925/A725/A520) and Immortalis‑G925 with validated 3nm implementations, delivering around 30%+ Android compute/graphics gains and 59% faster AI inference. It also highlights Arm’s KleidiAI library for popular AI frameworks, underscoring a hardware‑plus‑software push to accelerate AI smartphone development and adoption.

search_results.title: Arm Compute Subsystems reduce customer TTM
search_results.snippet: Industry analysis says CSS for Client packages hardened 3nm CPU/GPU implementations to cut partner time‑to‑market and improve PPA, with commitments from MediaTek (planning Cortex‑X925/Immortalis in Dimensity 9400) and collaboration with Samsung Foundry’s 3nm GAA. It frames CSS as a successor to TCS for faster delivery of Android flagship SoCs, complemented by Arm’s Kleidi AI/CV software.

Arm hiring plan for CPU microarchitectur.query: Arm hiring plan for CPU microarchitecture talent in Cambridge and Austin this year
Arm hiring plan for CPU microarchitectur.answer: Arm is actively hiring CPU microarchitecture talent in both Austin and Cambridge this year. In Austin, a Senior/Principal CPU Performance – Microarchitecture Exploration role posted in late September 2025 shows direct hiring for defining next‑gen Cortex‑X and Neoverse CPU microarchitectures. In the UK, a Senior SoC Design Engineer role posted in November 2025 includes Cambridge and calls for developing subsystem microarchitecture specifications, indicating microarchitecture-related hiring at the Cambridge hub. Arm is also investing in Cambridge’s computer architecture talent pipeline via a £3.5m donation to fund PhD students starting in 2025.

search_results.title: CPU Performance – Microarchitecture Exploration Engineer (Senior/Principal)
search_results.snippet: Arm’s CPU Performance team is hiring in Austin for a Senior/Principal Microarchitecture Exploration Engineer to help define next‑generation Cortex‑X and Neoverse CPUs by building performance models, studying workloads, and evaluating new microarchitectural ideas (Date posted: Sep. 22, 2025) — clear evidence of Austin microarchitecture hiring this year.

search_results.title: Senior SoC Design Engineer
search_results.snippet: Arm is recruiting a Senior SoC Design Engineer across UK sites including Cambridge (posted Nov. 05, 2025). Responsibilities include reviewing subsystem architecture, developing microarchitecture specifications, collaborating with verification and performance teams, and delivering RTL subsystems — indicating active microarchitecture‑related hiring in Cambridge.

search_results.title: Arm donates £3.5 million for Cambridge PhD students to study computer architecture and semiconductor design
search_results.snippet: Arm is funding 15 PhD students at Cambridge’s new CASCADE centre over five years starting in 2025, focused on computer architecture and semiconductor design. This investment underscores a strategic pipeline for CPU architecture talent in Cambridge alongside ongoing hiring.

Arm dependency on Synopsys and Cadence E.query: Arm dependency on Synopsys and Cadence EDA tool availability for key tapeouts
Arm dependency on Synopsys and Cadence E.answer: Arm’s key tapeouts rely on the availability of Synopsys and Cadence EDA tool flows. Both vendors co-develop optimized RTL-to-GDS reference flows, Rapid Adoption/QuickStart kits, and verification/emulation platforms with Arm to enable early-adopter tapeouts at advanced nodes (3 nm/5 nm/7 nm). These collaborations indicate that limited access to Synopsys/Cadence tools would directly jeopardize schedules and PPA targets for Arm-based SoCs.

search_results.title: Cadence expands Arm agreement for EDA tool verification
search_results.snippet: Cadence and Arm expanded their collaboration to provide a ‘fast path to tapeout’ for Arm’s TCS23 platform (Cortex‑X4, A720, A520; Immortalis/Mali GPUs), delivering RTL‑to‑GDS Rapid Adoption Kits for 3 nm and 5 nm and validating comprehensive verification flows. The toolchain spans Cerebrus, Genus, Innovus, Tempus, Voltus, Conformal, plus Helium, Palladium and Protium, underscoring Arm’s reliance on Cadence EDA to bring new IP to silicon quickly.

search_results.title: Cadence and Arm target faster path to tapeout
search_results.snippet: Cadence and Arm announced they are targeting a faster path to tapeout using Cadence digital and verification flows for Arm TCS23, with 3 nm/5 nm Rapid Adoption Kits and AI‑driven Cerebrus optimizations. Cadence reports significant timing, area, and leakage improvements on Cortex‑X4 and says the collaboration gets Arm’s latest CPUs/GPUs into customers’ hands faster—evidence of Arm’s dependence on Cadence tools for key tapeouts.

search_results.title: Synopsys Enables Tapeout Success for Early Adopters of Arm's Next Generation of Mobile IP
search_results.snippet: Synopsys and Arm collaborated to enable early‑adopter tapeouts of SoCs using Arm’s latest mobile IP (Cortex‑A78, Cortex‑X1, Mali‑G78) via Synopsys Fusion Design Platform, Verification Continuum, and DesignWare IP. Synopsys’ QuickStart Implementation Kits (QIKs) and reference flows demonstrate how Arm tapeouts depend on Synopsys tool availability to hit PPA and time‑to‑market targets.

Arm planned enhancements to Ethos NPU ro.query: Arm planned enhancements to Ethos NPU roadmap for on-device multimodal inference
Arm planned enhancements to Ethos NPU ro.answer: Arm’s Ethos NPU roadmap is adding native transformer acceleration, broader operator coverage, sparsity-aware compute (2/4), improved weight compression/bandwidth, and higher scalable performance to enable on‑device multimodal AI (e.g., vision + language/audio) at low power. The latest Ethos-U85 exemplifies this direction with up to 4 TOPS, 20% better efficiency vs. its predecessor, and full support for transformer models (e.g., TinyLlama) for local generative and vision tasks.

search_results.title: Arm Accelerates Edge AI with Latest Generation Ethos-U NPU and New IoT Reference Design Platform
search_results.snippet: Arm’s newest Ethos-U85 NPU lifts performance (up to 4 TOPS) and power efficiency while adding native support for Transformer Networks alongside CNNs, enabling local execution of vision and generative AI workloads. The update, designed to work with Armv9 Cortex-A CPUs, targets real-time on-device AI across audio/voice and vision pipelines—signaling the roadmap’s push toward multimodal inference on device.

search_results.title: How Arm's Machine Learning Solution Enables Vision Transformers (slides)
search_results.snippet: Arm’s 2024 presentation outlines the next-generation Ethos NPU enhancements: hardware-accelerated transformer operators, extended operator support, targeted +20% power efficiency, scalable MAC configurations (128–2048), and 2/4 sparsity that can double throughput on sparse layers. These planned upgrades are aimed at running larger, mixed-modality models efficiently on-device.

search_results.title: Arm Ethos-U85 NPU Raises Edge AI Performance and Efficiency
search_results.snippet: Independent analysis notes Ethos-U85 adds hardware operator chaining, an updated weight decoder, wider operator support, and transformer capability—allowing models like TinyLlama to fully map to the NPU without CPU fallback. These architectural changes reflect Arm’s roadmap to support on-device multimodal AI by boosting efficiency, bandwidth use, and model compatibility.

Arm expected Windows on Arm device attac.query: Arm expected Windows on Arm device attach rate at top three PC OEMs
Arm expected Windows on Arm device attac.answer: Arm’s CEO Rene Haas has said Arm could surpass a 50% share of Windows PCs within five years. Qualcomm’s CEO Cristiano Amon added that some major OEMs expect 40–60% of their Windows PC sales to be Snapdragon-based within three years—implying high Windows-on-Arm device attach at leading OEMs. While Arm hasn’t disclosed a precise attach-rate figure for the top three PC OEMs, public guidance points to attach rates in the 40–60% range at major OEMs within three years, aligned to a five-year goal of >50% Windows share.

search_results.title: Qualcomm CEO says Arm taking 50% of the Windows PC market in five years is realistic; some OEMs already expect Snapdragon chips to be 60% of their sales within three years
search_results.snippet: Cristiano Amon endorsed Arm CEO Rene Haas’s Windows PC ambition and said some OEMs plan for 40–60% of their Windows PC sales to be Snapdragon-based within three years, indicating high Windows‑on‑Arm device attach at major vendors.

search_results.title: Arm CEO aims to conquer half the Windows world in 5 years
search_results.snippet: Rene Haas told Reuters he believes Arm can exceed 50% share of Windows PCs in five years, with industry context noting today’s Arm PC base is small and that achieving this will require rapid OEM adoption across laptops and desktops.

search_results.title: Exclusive-Arm aims to capture 50% of PC market in five years, CEO says
search_results.snippet: Reuters interview: Arm sees Windows on Arm surpassing 50% within five years, backed by Microsoft’s stronger developer tooling; Qualcomm leads the first wave, with OEMs like Asus and Dell preparing Arm‑based Windows PCs.

Arm updated assessment of RISC-V competi.query: Arm updated assessment of RISC-V competition in mobile and embedded markets
Arm updated assessment of RISC-V competi.answer: Recent industry sources indicate RISC‑V is intensifying competitive pressure on Arm in embedded systems and is beginning to make inroads into mobile via wearables, while Arm remains dominant in smartphone application processors. Omdia projects RISC‑V could approach a quarter of processors by 2030, with strongest growth in automotive and continued presence in IoT/embedded, and Thoughtworks notes RISC‑V’s open, modular design offers similar per‑watt efficiency to Arm but lower absolute performance. Qualcomm and Google’s RISC‑V wearable platform for Wear OS underscores early but material encroachment into the mobile ecosystem.

search_results.title: RISC-V adoption will be accelerated by AI, according to new Omdia research
search_results.snippet: Omdia forecasts RISC‑V processors will account for almost a quarter of the global market by 2030. The open, license‑free ISA, long associated with deeply embedded/IoT, is expanding into more advanced compute and AI; the fastest growth is in automotive while industrial remains largest. Omdia adds RISC‑V makes the most sense in novel applications where no existing Arm product is in place, highlighting rising competitive pressure on Arm in embedded and adjacent mobile segments.

search_results.title: RISC-V for embedded | Technology Radar | Thoughtworks
search_results.snippet: Thoughtworks notes RISC‑V’s per‑watt performance is similar to Arm’s but it lags in absolute performance; as an open, modular ISA not tied to a single vendor it is attractive for embedded systems where licensing costs matter. The embedded RISC‑V ecosystem is maturing (e.g., SiFive, Espressif, Linux‑capable MCUs/MPUs), supporting the view that RISC‑V is an increasingly credible competitor to Arm in embedded markets.

search_results.title: Qualcomm and Google launch RISC-V wearables chip collaboration
search_results.snippet: Qualcomm and Google are developing RISC‑V Snapdragon Wear processors for Wear OS, substituting Arm CPU cores in future wearable SoCs. This signals concrete RISC‑V inroads into mobile via wearables even as Arm remains dominant in smartphone application processors, illustrating an early but meaningful competitive shift in the mobile ecosystem.

Arm current guidance on share-based comp.query: Arm current guidance on share-based compensation expense trajectory for FY2026
Arm current guidance on share-based comp.answer: Arm has not provided explicit FY2026 guidance for share-based compensation (SBC). Management withheld full‑year FY2026 guidance due to tariff/macro uncertainty and only gives quarterly non‑GAAP operating expense targets (which exclude SBC), guiding ~$625m in Q1 and ~$655m in Q2 as R&D investment accelerates. No breakout or trajectory for SBC expense in FY2026 is disclosed.

search_results.title: Arm Holdings plc Shareholder Letter (Q1 FYE26)
search_results.snippet: Arm’s Q1 FYE26 shareholder letter provides only quarterly guidance—non‑GAAP operating expense of ~$625m (Q1) and ~$655m (Q2) as the company accelerates R&D—while stating it cannot provide forward‑looking GAAP-to-non‑GAAP reconciliations. The letter does not give an FY2026 share‑based compensation outlook, so no SBC trajectory is provided.

search_results.title: Arm Q1 2026 Earnings Call Transcript
search_results.snippet: On the Q1 FY2026 call, the CFO offered quarterly guidance only (Q2 revenue $1.01–$1.11 billion; non‑GAAP opex ~ $655m) and emphasized accelerated investment; no full‑year FY2026 guidance or separate share‑based compensation outlook was disclosed.

search_results.title: ARM Earnings: Tariffs Shut Down 2026 Guidance, Revenue Growth Still Strong
search_results.snippet: Morningstar reports management ‘shut down’ FY2026 guidance amid tariff uncertainty, offering only directional revenue commentary. This indicates the company is not providing full‑year expense guidance—hence no disclosed share‑based compensation expense trajectory for FY2026.

Arm expected effect of UK and US R&D tax.query: Arm expected effect of UK and US R&D tax credits on FY2026 net income
Arm expected effect of UK and US R&D tax.answer: Arm has not disclosed a standalone dollar figure for the FY2026 net income impact from UK and US R&D tax credits. However, management highlights that R&D tax credits materially lowered taxes in FY2025 Q4 (a 45.8% GAAP tax benefit primarily due to windfall gains and R&D credits) and reported a low 15.0% non-GAAP effective tax rate in Q1 FY2026. This indicates the expected effect is a continued tailwind via a lower effective tax rate supporting FY2026 net income, rather than a separately quantified amount.

search_results.title: Arm Holdings plc Shareholder Letter (Q4 FYE25) — EX-99.2
search_results.snippet: Arm states its Q4 FYE25 GAAP effective tax rate was a 45.8% benefit primarily due to windfall gains and R&D tax credits, with a non-GAAP effective tax rate of 14.0%. This shows R&D tax credits materially boosted net income heading into FY2026.

search_results.title: Arm Holdings plc Shareholder Letter (Q1 FYE26) — EX-99.2
search_results.snippet: For Q1 FYE26, Arm reports a non-GAAP effective tax rate of 15.0% (GAAP 11.0%) in its financial overview. While no separate UK/US R&D credit amount is broken out, the low effective tax rate implies ongoing tax credit benefits supporting FY2026 net income.

search_results.title: Q1 2026 Arm Holdings PLC Earnings Call Transcript
search_results.snippet: Management discussed Q2 FY26 guidance and non-GAAP EPS but did not provide a discrete figure for the UK/US R&D tax credit impact on FY2026 net income. Tax effects appear reflected in the effective tax rate rather than as a separately quantified item.

Arm projected operating margin range at.query: Arm projected operating margin range at FY2026 revenue midpoint and mix
Arm projected operating margin range at.answer: Arm management has guided to “solid 40+%” non‑GAAP operating margins for FY2025 and “certainly for next year” (FY2026), implying a low‑40s margin at the FY2026 revenue midpoint/mix. Recent prints bracket that range: 45% in Q3 FYE25 and 39% in Q1 FYE26, so a reasonable projected operating margin range is about 40%–45% at the FY2026 revenue midpoint and mix.

search_results.title: Arm Holdings plc American Depositary Shares Earnings Call Transcript Q2 2024
search_results.snippet: On the Q2 FY2024 call, CFO Jason Child said they still expect to deliver “solid 40‑plus percent overall margin for this year and then certainly for next year,” while working toward a 60% long‑term target—signaling a low‑40s non‑GAAP operating margin outlook into FY2026.

search_results.title: Arm Reports Record Revenue in Q3
search_results.snippet: For Q3 FYE25, Arm reported non‑GAAP operating income of $442m on $983m revenue, a 45% non‑GAAP operating margin. This recent high watermark helps frame the upper bound of Arm’s operating margin range heading into FY2026.

search_results.title: Arm Holdings plc SoftBank Investor Briefing (Q1 FYE26)
search_results.snippet: The Q1 FYE26 investor deck shows a 39% non‑GAAP operating margin alongside $1.05b revenue and Q2 guidance of $1.01b–$1.11b, illustrating the lower end of recent margins near the FY2026 revenue mix and midpoint.

Arm timeline to introduce reference SoC.query: Arm timeline to introduce reference SoC blueprints bundling CPU, GPU, NPU, interconnect
Arm timeline to introduce reference SoC.answer: Arm introduced production‑ready reference SoC blueprints in May 2024 under its Compute Subsystems (CSS) for Client, bundling an Armv9.2 CPU cluster, Immortalis GPU, and CoreLink interconnect with hardened 3 nm physical implementations aimed at first‑generation 3 nm Android SoCs. Arm says it does not yet supply NPUs for phones/PCs, but its “done‑and‑baked” platforms are designed so partners can tightly couple their own NPUs to the CPU/GPU/interconnect.

search_results.title: Arm CSS for Client: The Compute Platform for AI-powered Consumer Experiences
search_results.snippet: Announced May 29, 2024, Arm’s CSS for Client is a production‑ready compute subsystem that bundles an Armv9.2 CPU cluster (Cortex‑X925/A725/A520), Immortalis‑G925 GPU, and CoreLink interconnect with tape‑out‑ready 3 nm physical implementations; Arm says CSS will be part of the first generation of Android SoCs on 3 nm, providing a fast path to silicon.

search_results.title: Arm introduces new designs, offers software for AI on smartphones: Details
search_results.snippet: Reuters (May 30, 2024): Arm shifts to delivering ready‑to‑manufacture physical blueprints co‑developed with Samsung and TSMC, while emphasizing it does not currently supply NPUs for phones/PCs; instead, Arm aims to offer more “done and baked” SoC platforms so partners can tightly couple their own NPUs alongside Arm CPUs/GPUs and interconnect.

search_results.title: Arm Unveils 2024 Compute Platform: 3nm, Cortex-X925, Cortex-A725, Immortalis-G925
search_results.snippet: Coverage from May 29, 2024 explains Arm’s 2024 Client Compute Subsystem: a reference platform combining DSU‑120 CPU cluster (Cortex‑X925/A725/A520), 5th‑gen Immortalis‑G925 GPU, and system interconnect, optimized for TSMC 3 nm with proven physical implementations to speed time‑to‑market versus prior soft-IP only approaches.

Arm updated estimate of CSS licenses sig.query: Arm updated estimate of CSS licenses signed and active design programs
Arm updated estimate of CSS licenses sig.answer: Arm’s latest update indicates it has signed 16 CSS licenses across 10 companies (up from 13 earlier in 2025). First‑generation CSS is already in market with five customers, and management highlights active design programs spanning data center, PC, mobile, and automotive as CSS adoption accelerates.

search_results.title: Arm Q1 FYE26 Revenue Exceeds $1 Billion for Second Consecutive Quarter
search_results.snippet: Arm reports signing three additional CSS licenses in the quarter—two for datacenter chips and one for PCs—bringing the total to 16 CSS licenses across 10 companies. The update underscores broad CSS momentum alongside Armv9 adoption and expanding Neoverse deployments.

search_results.title: Arm plots move up the stack with push into end-to-end silicon
search_results.snippet: On its Q1 FY26 call, Arm said it has signed 16 CSS licenses with 10 companies, more than double the year-ago count, with first‑generation CSS already in market at five customers. The quarter added three CSS deals (two datacenter, one PC), indicating active design activity across segments.

search_results.title: Arm 2026 Q1 Financials
search_results.snippet: Analyst summary of Arm’s quarter notes CSS licensing picked up multiple new customers, lifting the total to 16 CSS licenses across 10 companies, with a mix of 9 client, 6 infrastructure, and 1 automotive. Management calls CSS the preferred starting point, implying multiple ongoing design programs.

Arm forecast for IoT royalty stabilizati.query: Arm forecast for IoT royalty stabilization and catalysts for recovery by quarter
Arm forecast for IoT royalty stabilizati.answer: Arm said industrial IoT and networking weakness persisted into Q1 FY2025 due to inventory corrections, with Q2 expected to be the trough. By Q3 FY2025 (December quarter), management noted IoT royalties showed signs of recovery and the shareholder update cited “IoT improvement” as a royalty driver. Catalysts highlighted were rising Armv9 mix, the ramp of Compute Subsystems (CSS) in the second half, and share gains in cloud and automotive.

search_results.title: Arm Reports Record Revenue in Q3
search_results.snippet: Arm’s Q3 FYE25 update states royalty revenue rose 23% YoY, driven by Armv9 adoption, the ramp of Arm Compute Subsystems (CSS), IoT improvement, and increased data center usage—indicating IoT royalties began recovering in the December quarter.

search_results.title: Arm Holdings (ARM) Q3 2025 Earnings Call Transcript
search_results.snippet: In Q3 FY2025, CFO Jason Child said royalty revenue from IoT showed signs of recovery after multiple quarters of weakness, with overall growth helped by continued Armv9 adoption and initial shipments of CSS-based chips.

search_results.title: Arm Holdings (ARM) Q1 2025 Earnings Call Transcript
search_results.snippet: In Q1 FY2025, management flagged continued weakness in IoT and networking from an industrial inventory correction, guided Q2 as the low point of the year, and cited catalysts for later recovery: rising Armv9 mix, share gains in cloud/automotive, and the initial ramp of CSS in the second half.

Arm status of partnerships with TSMC and.query: Arm status of partnerships with TSMC and Samsung at 2nm and below nodes
Arm status of partnerships with TSMC and.answer: Arm’s 2nm collaborations are active with both foundries. With Samsung Foundry, Arm is co‑optimizing next‑gen Cortex‑X on Samsung’s GAA and jointly enabling a 2nm GAA AI CPU chiplet platform. With TSMC, Arm’s Neoverse CSS is being used in a joint 2nm (N2) CPU chiplet effort with Socionext on TSMC’s process. Public disclosures focus on 2nm; Arm has not explicitly announced sub‑2nm (A16/SF1.4) partnerships yet.

search_results.title: Samsung Electronics Collaborates with Arm on Optimized Next Gen Cortex-X CPU Using Samsung Foundry’s Latest GAA Process Technology
search_results.snippet: Samsung and Arm announced a collaboration to deliver an optimized next‑generation Cortex‑X CPU on Samsung Foundry’s latest GAA process, stating bold plans to reinvent 2‑nanometer GAA for next‑gen data center and infrastructure silicon alongside an AI chiplet solution—confirming an active 2nm partnership and DTCO focus.

search_results.title: Socionext Announces Collaboration with Arm and TSMC on 2nm Multi-Core Leading CPU Chiplet Development
search_results.snippet: Socionext, Arm and TSMC are co‑developing a power‑optimized 32‑core CPU chiplet on TSMC’s 2nm (N2) technology using Arm Neoverse CSS, targeting hyperscale, 5/6G, DPU and edge markets; TSMC said it looks forward to extending this collaboration into the 2nm generation—evidence of Arm–TSMC engagement at 2nm.

search_results.title: Arm Total Design Ignites Growing Ecosystem of Arm-based Silicon for a Sustainable AI Datacenter
search_results.snippet: Arm says it, Samsung Foundry, ADTechnology and Rebellions are partnering on an AI CPU chiplet platform implemented on Samsung Foundry’s 2nm GAA process, aiming for 2–3x GenAI efficiency—further detailing the Arm–Samsung 2nm collaboration with Neoverse CSS and an expanding chiplet ecosystem.

Arm policy on device-value-based royalty.query: Arm policy on device-value-based royalty pricing and rollout timeline by segment
Arm policy on device-value-based royalty.answer: Reports indicate Arm has proposed shifting royalties from a per-chip basis to the value of the end device, with OEMs paying royalties directly. The initial rollout is aimed at smartphones as early as 2024, with the OEM-licensing model extending to other device categories such as notebooks; major architectural licensees like Apple and Samsung would be largely unaffected. Beyond smartphones, Arm has not publicly confirmed firm segment-by-segment timelines for PCs, IoT, or automotive.

search_results.title: How Arm aims to squeeze device makers for cash rather than pocket pennies for cores
search_results.snippet: Citing FT, The Register describes Arm’s plan to charge royalties based on end‑device value and to license directly to OEMs; chipmakers would use ‘development licenses’ while device makers pay on the sale price of gear like phones and notebooks, aligning with Arm’s stated intent to license OEMs/cloud providers.

search_results.title: Report: Arm proposes change to IP royalty model
search_results.snippet: eeNews, summarizing FT, says Arm wants to move from chip-value royalties to equipment-value royalties, initially in smartphones where it dominates; the shift could start as soon as 2024, with Apple and Samsung less affected due to architectural licenses, implying a higher per-unit royalty take.

search_results.title: Arm changes business plan ahead of US IPO
search_results.snippet: TechHQ reports Arm told customers it will charge royalties based on the value of the device rather than the chip to lift revenue ahead of its IPO, using smartphones as the key example; it notes industry pushback and that Apple has a special arrangement, reflecting broader pricing changes.

Arm expected PC royalty per unit uplift.query: Arm expected PC royalty per unit uplift versus smartphone royalty rates
Arm expected PC royalty per unit uplift.answer: HSBC expects Arm’s AI PC CPUs to pay royalties of about 10% of CPU ASP, up from roughly 5%, implying around a 2x per‑unit uplift for PCs. For smartphones, Bank of America pegs Armv9 royalty rates at about 2–4.5% (vs. 1–2% for Armv8), and Morningstar notes smartphone royalties jumped despite modest unit growth because v9 commands higher rates. Net: PC royalties are expected to be roughly double smartphone rates, and dollar-per-unit proceeds should be materially higher given PC CPU ASPs.

search_results.title: Arm stock downgraded at HSBC amid less bullish AI PC narrative, Android challenges
search_results.snippet: HSBC cut Arm to Reduce, warning that while royalties are rising, AI PC CPU royalties are expected to double from ~5% to ~10% of CPU ASP, with uncertainty on unit TAM. The note also flags Android softness and that smartphones still account for over 60% of sales—setting a clear PC-vs-smartphone royalty gap.

search_results.title: Three Growth Drivers of Arm | AI Dehydration (Bank of America summary)

Arm actions to reduce contract cycle tim.query: Arm actions to reduce contract cycle times for architectural and technology licenses

search_results.title: Arm Flexible Access

search_results.title: Flexible Licensing, Boundless Innovation: How Arm is Accelerating Partner Success
search_results.snippet: Arm evolved its licensing to speed partner engagement by launching Flexible Access and Total Access—broad IP access “without complex licensing terms,” manufacturing rights included, and pay-at-tape-out/distribution. Arm competitive response to x86 server e.query: Arm competitive response to x86 server efficiency gains from Intel and AMD roadmaps
Arm competitive response to x86 server e.answer: Arm’s competitive response centers on accelerating its Neoverse roadmap and Compute Subsystems (CSS) to let hyperscalers ship highly efficient, custom Arm server CPUs that target performance-per-watt and TCO, directly countering x86 efficiency gains from Intel’s Sierra Forest/Granite Rapids and AMD’s Zen 5/Zen 5c (Turin Dense). In practice, partners like Google (Axion) and Ampere (AmpereOne) show strong per‑vCPU throughput and energy efficiency versus recent x86 parts, while Nvidia’s Grace demonstrates memory- and power‑efficient HPC/server performance. Together, these moves emphasize core density, LPDDR5X/DDR5 efficiency, and faster time-to-market to compete with x86’s efficiency-focused roadmaps.

search_results.title: Arm Says Neoverse Is A More Universal Compute Substrate Than X86

He positions Neoverse + CSS as Arm’s rack-scale, AI-era answer to x86, enabling rapid, efficient server CPUs that rival x86 incumbents across cloud and datacenter workloads.

search_results.title: Google Axion Challenges x86 in Cloud Workloads with Arm-Based Advantage

Axion powers C4A instances across GKE, Cloud SQL, AlloyDB, and more, illustrating Arm’s cloud response to x86’s efficiency-focused roadmaps.

It contrasts this with Intel’s Sierra Forest (up to 288 E‑cores) and AMD’s Turin Dense (192 Zen 5c cores), framing Arm’s core‑density and TCO strategy as a direct response to x86 efficiency gains.

Arm specific goals for Linux ecosystem p.query: Arm specific goals for Linux ecosystem performance improvements on Arm servers
Arm specific goals for Linux ecosystem p.answer: Arm’s current goals to improve Linux performance on Arm servers include regularly upgrading toolchains and math libraries (Arm Compiler for Linux and Arm Performance Libraries) tuned for Neoverse platforms to deliver measurable speedups for SPEC and HPC workloads. In parallel, the Arm/Linux community is aligning upstream kernel work via Linaro’s forum on scheduler capacity reporting and CPU frequency capping to improve scheduling decisions and stability. Practical datacenter testing shows Linux on aarch64 can hit high throughput with proper BIOS and kernel tuning, reinforcing these performance-focused efforts.

These updates aim to accelerate Linux workloads on Arm servers through improved compilers and optimized math libraries.

These goals target better scheduling decisions and performance across Arm systems, including servers.

Results demonstrate that Linux on Arm servers can meet datacenter performance targets with practical tuning, informing performance improvement goals.

Arm timeline for expanding CXL features.answer: Arm’s Neoverse rollout shows a staged path: Neoverse V2 can run the CXL 2.0 memory pooling protocol, while broader cross-CPU memory sharing via switches is tied to PCIe 6.0/CXL 3.0 on the next “Poseidon” generation. In practice, Arm materials from 2023 highlight CXL 1.1 maturing for memory expansion with Arm CPUs and CXL 2.0 enabling memory pooling next, and Arm’s current docs confirm CXL 2.0 Type‑3 (memory expander) support on Neoverse N2 as a foundation for pooling.

This sets the timeline: V2 for CXL 2.0 pooling, with broader pooling/sharing arriving alongside CXL 3.0.

search_results.title: Compute Express Link — Neoverse Reference Design Platform

The firmware and kernel integration map remote CXL memory as a NUMA node, illustrating current, production‑oriented CXL memory expansion on Neoverse that underpins future pooling.

search_results.title: Enabling CXL in Heterogeneous Compute with Arm | 4x13
search_results.snippet: Arm’s Eddie Ramirez outlines the progression: CXL 1.1 brings memory expansion to Arm CPUs (maturing in 2023), Arm is delivering CXL 2.0 to enable memory pooling for higher utilization, and the next step is heterogeneous compute with shared memory across a CXL fabric—framing the near‑term and next‑gen timeline for pooling on Neoverse.

Arm policy for minimum cash balance and.query: Arm policy for minimum cash balance and potential debt issuance triggers
Arm policy for minimum cash balance and.answer: The U.S. Treasury’s policy is to hold cash in the Treasury General Account generally sufficient to cover one week of outflows, with a rough minimum around $150 billion. When cash needs rise or after events like a debt-limit impasse, Treasury rebuilds its cash balance primarily by increasing bill issuance (including short-tenor bills and cash management bills), adjusting auction sizes gradually to remain regular and predictable while often holding balances above the minimum to smooth week-to-week variability.

search_results.title: Debt Issuance Modeling Framework – Office of Debt Management (2015)
search_results.snippet: Treasury formalized a precautionary cash policy to hold a TGA balance generally sufficient to cover one week of outflows, subject to a roughly $150B minimum; after a debt limit resolution, Treasury projected rebuilding cash to about $325B, with most of the increase coming from higher bill issuance—underscoring bills as the main lever to raise cash quickly while keeping issuance regular and predictable.

search_results.title: Treasury Cash Management Approach (Supplemental QRA, Q1 2022)
search_results.snippet: Treasury details its practice of forecasting one‑week‑ahead outflows (including gross maturities) and keeping cash at or above the one‑week minimum ($150B floor), adjusting bill auction sizes gradually; to avoid market disruption it often allows balances above the minimum, typically maintaining around seven business days of liquidity.

search_results.title: Potential 6‑Week Benchmark – Treasury Borrowing Advisory Committee (Apr 30, 2024)
search_results.snippet: Following the June 2023 debt‑limit impasse, Treasury began regular weekly issuance of a 6‑week cash management bill to rebuild a depleted cash balance and finance the deficit; the brief discusses making the 6‑week a benchmark and highlights CMBs as short‑term cash management tools that Treasury can tap to replenish liquidity.

Arm competitive positioning against RISC.answer: Arm retains a strong lead in automotive with its Automotive Enhanced (AE) IP, Safety Ready ISO 26262-certified portfolio and pre-verified compute subsystems, used by the vast majority of automakers, which strengthens its position versus emerging RISC-V options. At the same time, RISC-V is gaining traction in microcontrollers and automotive, with TechInsights highlighting new automotive-grade RISC-V MCUs (e.g., Great Wall’s Zijing M100) and Infineon announcing a RISC-V AURIX MCU family alongside its Arm-based lines. The competitive balance is Arm’s safety, tooling and ecosystem scale versus RISC-V’s openness and customization drawing adoption in MCUs and selected auto domains.
