search_results.snippet: Infineon announces plans for an automotive RISC‑V AURIX microcontroller family, complementing its Arm‑based TRAVEO and PSoC lines. As a major automotive MCU supplier, its move signals growing RISC‑V adoption in automotive microcontrollers and heightens competitive pressure on Arm in this segment.

Arm expected impact of UK corporate tax.query: Arm expected impact of UK corporate tax changes on FY2026 effective tax rate
Arm expected impact of UK corporate tax.answer: Arm’s Q1 FY2026 shareholder letter shows a non-GAAP effective tax rate of 15% (GAAP 11%), suggesting a mid‑teens run-rate early in FY2026. UK legislation keeps the corporation tax main rate at 25% and the small profits rate at 19% for the financial year beginning April 2026, and HMRC shows these rates have been stable since the April 2023 increase. Therefore, UK corporate tax changes are not expected to materially raise Arm’s FY2026 effective tax rate; any movement should mainly reflect mix and incentives (e.g., R&D/Patent Box) rather than headline rate changes.

search_results.title: Arm Holdings plc – Shareholder Letter (Q1 FY2026) – SEC 6‑K Exhibit 99.2
search_results.snippet: Arm reports in its Q1 FY2026 shareholder letter that the GAAP effective tax rate was 11.0% and the non‑GAAP effective tax rate was 15.0%, indicating a mid‑teens ETR at the start of FY2026.

search_results.title: Clause 13 - Charge and main rate for financial year 2026
search_results.snippet: UK Finance Bill Clause 13 sets the corporation tax main rate at 25% and the small profits rate at 19% for the financial year beginning April 2026, with the Government committing to cap the main rate at 25% for the Parliament—implying no new headline rate increase for FY2026.

search_results.title: Corporation Tax rates and allowances
search_results.snippet: HMRC’s official rates show the main corporation tax rate at 25% and the small profits rate at 19% (with marginal relief) since the April 2023 change and in 2024–2025, evidencing stability that continues into the 2026 financial year.

Arm strategy to grow share in edge AI ga.query: Arm strategy to grow share in edge AI gateways and industrial IoT controllers
Arm strategy to grow share in edge AI ga.answer: Arm is targeting growth in edge AI gateways and industrial IoT controllers by launching a cohesive Armv9 IoT edge AI platform that pairs the ultra‑efficient Cortex‑A320 CPU with the Ethos‑U85 NPU to enable on‑device AI (including large and small language models) with built‑in security. The strategy couples integrated hardware and software (Kleidi AI, optimized Arm ML libraries), reference subsystems (Corstone) and cloud‑based tools (Arm Virtual Hardware) to cut time‑to‑market and ensure portability from cloud to edge, while ecosystem partnerships (AWS, Siemens, Eurotech, Renesas, Advantech) accelerate adoption in industrial automation and gateways.

search_results.title: Arm intros edge platform to bring AI workloads closer to the IoT action
search_results.snippet: Arm introduces an Armv9 edge AI platform optimized for IoT that combines the new Cortex‑A320 CPU and Ethos‑U85 NPU to run billion‑parameter models on‑device; it brings SVE2 and security features (PAC, BTI, MTE) to small Cortex‑A IoT devices and extends Kleidi AI for faster development, with endorsements from AWS, Eurotech, Renesas and Siemens highlighting industrial edge use cases.

search_results.title: Edge AI
search_results.snippet: Arm outlines its edge AI strategy for IoT by integrating Cortex CPUs, Ethos NPUs and Corstone subsystems with software resources to accelerate time‑to‑market; Industrial IoT is a core segment, and the page links to the Armv9 edge AI platform and developer tools for building intelligent gateways and controllers with performance, energy efficiency and security.

search_results.title: Accelerating Edge AI Innovation: Tools & Strategies for IoT Differentiation
search_results.snippet: This VDC Research report explains how Arm’s ecosystem—NN SDK, CMSIS‑NN, Arm Compute Library, tight integration with LiteRT/TFLite and Ethos‑U NPUs, plus cloud‑based Arm Virtual Hardware—helps OEMs ‘shift development left’ and speed edge AI deployment from gateways to end nodes on Armv9, addressing complexity, security and scalability requirements for industrial gateways/controllers.

Arm status of compliance programs for US.query: Arm status of compliance programs for US EAR and UK export control regulations
Arm status of compliance programs for US.answer: Arm states it operates a formal, company-wide trade compliance program managed by Arm Trade Compliance, with a CEO-level commitment to strict adherence to export controls and sanctions. Its Terms and Conditions include an Export policy requiring all stakeholders to follow applicable export and customs laws and provide a contact for ECCN requests, reflecting active compliance with the U.S. EAR and UK regimes. Arm also publishes export classifications for its IP and notes relevant items in its packages are not listed on the UK Strategic Export Control List, evidencing alignment with UK export control requirements.

search_results.title: Terms and Conditions of Use
search_results.snippet: Arm’s Terms and Conditions include an Export section stating it is Arm policy to operate in strict compliance with applicable export and trade controls and sanctions, and that customers, partners, employees, and contractors must adhere to export and customs laws. It directs ECCN requests to Arm Trade Compliance (tradecompliance@arm.com), indicating an active program aligned with U.S. EAR and UK export control frameworks.

search_results.title: Arm’s Commitment to Compliance with Export Controls and Sanctions
search_results.snippet: Arm’s CEO affirms a company-wide governance framework for export, sanctions, and customs compliance managed by Arm Trade Compliance, committing to strict adherence to global export control and sanctions laws. The letter emphasizes obligations on all stakeholders and points to Arm’s Export policy page for more information.

search_results.title: Export Classification of Arm Products
search_results.snippet: Arm publishes U.S. Export Control Classification Numbers (ECCNs) for various Arm IP (e.g., 3E991, 3D991, EAR99) and notes that products licensed in these packages are not listed on the UK Strategic Export Control list or the EU Dual-Use List. This demonstrates classification under the U.S. EAR and alignment with UK export control requirements.

Arm details on collaborations with Micro.query: Arm details on collaborations with Microsoft and Google for AI PC ecosystems
Arm details on collaborations with Micro.answer: Arm’s AI PC work with Microsoft centers on integrating its KleidiAI into ONNX Runtime to speed on‑device inference for Windows on Arm and Copilot+ PCs, yielding up to ~2.4x faster prompt processing and improved Phi‑3 token generation without app rewrites. With Google, Arm supports Chrome’s native Arm64 on Windows to boost performance and AI-in‑browser workloads, and partners via MediaTek to bring Armv9 CPUs and Immortalis GPUs to Chromebook Plus devices for on‑device generative AI—expanding AI PC experiences across Windows and ChromeOS.

search_results.title: Arm and Microsoft Collaboration Supercharges AI Experiences for Applications on Arm-based PC and Mobile Devices
search_results.snippet: Arm and Microsoft integrate Arm’s KleidiAI into ONNX Runtime to accelerate AI on Windows on Arm and Copilot+ PCs. Arm reports up to 2.4x faster prompt throughput and a 12% token‑generation uplift on Phi‑3 on Armv9 Windows PCs, making Microsoft 365 and Copilot AI features run more efficiently without developer changes, while broadening edge AI across PCs and mobiles.

search_results.title: MediaTek’s Arm-based Kompanio Ultra Enables Powerful Generative AI Experiences on Chromebook Plus Devices
search_results.snippet: Arm and MediaTek introduce the Kompanio Ultra to the Chromebook Plus line, bringing Armv9 CPUs (Cortex‑X925/A725) and an Immortalis‑G925 GPU to enable on‑device generative AI, smarter collaboration, and rich multimedia with all‑day efficiency. The Arm compute platform effectively turns Chromebooks into AI‑capable PCs for creativity and productivity across the ChromeOS ecosystem.

search_results.title: Arm-native Google Chrome Enhances Windows on Arm Performance
search_results.snippet: Arm details Google’s native Arm64 Chrome for Windows on Arm, showing 3x+ Speedometer 3.0 gains versus emulated x86, faster scripting/rendering, and better battery life. The native browser also improves AI-in‑browser workloads (e.g., TensorFlow.js MobileNet), reinforcing Windows on Arm’s growing app ecosystem for AI PCs.

Arm initiatives to reduce customer integ.query: Arm initiatives to reduce customer integration costs and improve time-to-revenue
Arm initiatives to reduce customer integ.answer: Arm is reducing customer integration costs and improving time-to-revenue by delivering pre-validated compute subsystems (Neoverse CSS) that offload non‑differentiated integration and validation work, cutting NRE and accelerating time-to-silicon by up to a year. Its Arm Total Design ecosystem further lowers cost and friction by providing preferential access to CSS, pre‑integrated IP/EDA tools, design services, and foundry support to speed custom silicon. Arm’s SystemReady compliance program standardizes hardware/firmware and provides automated test suites and pre‑silicon checks so software “just works,” reducing integration and maintenance costs and shortening time to market.

search_results.title: Neoverse Compute Subsystems (CSS) – Fastest Path to Production Silicon
search_results.snippet: Arm Neoverse CSS are validated, performance‑optimized compute subsystems that offload non‑differentiated integration and validation, reducing risk and NRE while accelerating CPU time‑to‑market by up to one year. By delivering a pre‑verified subsystem (with SystemReady SR compliance and platform software), partners can focus on differentiation, cut integration costs, and move to revenue faster.

search_results.title: Arm Total Design for Specialized Infrastructure Computing
search_results.snippet: Arm Total Design is an ecosystem that speeds and simplifies CSS‑based custom silicon by offering preferential access to Neoverse CSS, pre‑integrated IP and EDA tools, expert design services, foundry support, and commercial firmware. This coordinated enablement lowers development friction and cost while accelerating time to market—and thus time to revenue—for custom SoCs.

search_results.title: Arm SystemReady Compliance Program
search_results.snippet: Arm SystemReady standardizes hardware and firmware so OSs run without modification on compliant Arm platforms. With automated test suites and a pre‑silicon compliance program, SystemReady reduces integration and troubleshooting effort, lowers lifecycle and maintenance costs, and helps vendors ship sooner—improving time‑to‑market and time‑to‑revenue.

Arm quantified license deal cycle time f.query: Arm quantified license deal cycle time from initial engagement to revenue recognition
Arm quantified license deal cycle time f.answer: Arm’s licensing deals typically take about 6–24 months to negotiate to contract signature. Under ASC 606, Arm often recognizes a meaningful share of license consideration at or shortly after signing (management notes a mix where roughly half of quarterly license revenue comes from previously signed backlog with the rest from new in‑quarter signings). Royalty revenue tied to those licenses generally lags by about 2–3 years as chips are developed and begin shipping.

search_results.title: Message from Arm CEO—SoftBank Group Report 2024
search_results.snippet: Arm explains that after a license is signed, customers need time to design and commercialize chips; as a result, licenses signed today are not expected to yield royalty revenue for at least 2–3 years. Successful chips can then produce royalty streams for years or even decades.

search_results.title: ARM Q3 2024 Earnings Call Transcript
search_results.snippet: Management describes how quarterly license revenue is a mix of backlog (previously signed deals hitting delivery milestones within the quarter) and new deals signed in-quarter, noting some shorter cycle deals due to AI. This implies recognition can occur at signing or near-term milestones, while license revenue remains inherently lumpy.

search_results.title: How ARM licenses it’s IP for production
search_results.snippet: ARM says it typically takes 6–24 months to negotiate a licensing deal, with the legal and royalty terms adding complexity and prolonging the process from initial engagement to a signed agreement.

Arm planned enhancements to interconnect.query: Arm planned enhancements to interconnect IP for chiplet-based heterogeneous systems
Arm planned enhancements to interconnect.answer: Arm is extending its interconnect IP to multi-die chiplet systems by introducing AMBA CHI C2C, which packetizes on-chip CHI for chiplet-to-chiplet links and can run over UCIe to preserve unified memory, security, and low-latency behavior. Arm has also committed to an open AXI C2C spec and is updating AMBA for on-/off-chip interfaces while coordinating with industry standards (UCIe, PCIe, CXL) and its Chiplet System Architecture (CSA) to enable interoperable, heterogeneous chiplet systems.

search_results.title: Ecosystem Collaboration Drives New AMBA Specification for Chiplets
search_results.snippet: Arm extends AMBA to chiplet-based systems with the CHI C2C specification, which reuses on-chip CHI by packetizing it for chiplet-to-chiplet transport and layering over UCIe’s streaming interface to maintain coherency, security, and low latency; Arm also commits to an open AXI C2C spec to align with CHI C2C and improve future chiplet interoperability across heterogeneous systems.

search_results.title: Chiplets Make Progress Using Interconnects As Glue
search_results.snippet: Arm describes interconnects as the ‘glue’ for chiplets—spanning on-chip NoCs and UCIe die-to-die links—and notes AMBA CHI (and CHI C2C) provide a packetized, widely used base for connecting chiplets atop suitable PHY/link layers; chiplet interconnects evolve from on-SoC/on-board fabrics but add layered protocol/PHY needs to match application, latency, and power targets.

search_results.title: A closer look at Arm’s chiplet game plan
search_results.snippet: EDN reports Arm is updating AMBA specifications for on-chip and off-chip interfaces to support chiplet designs, engaging with UCIe for die-to-die PHY standardization, and using its Chiplet System Architecture (CSA) to guide partitioning so Arm-based SoCs can be disaggregated into interoperable chiplets—reducing fragmentation and enabling heterogeneous systems.

Arm outlook for competitive dynamics wit.query: Arm outlook for competitive dynamics with x86 in AI PCs over next year
Arm outlook for competitive dynamics wit.answer: Over the next year, Arm’s early lead in AI PCs via Qualcomm Snapdragon X-powered Copilot+ laptops will face accelerating x86 competition as Intel’s Lunar Lake and AMD’s Ryzen AI 300 join Copilot+ with 40+ TOPS NPUs and new features rolling out from late 2024. Microsoft is broadening Copilot+ beyond Arm, while Arm’s leadership signals aggressive share ambitions; the balance will hinge on app compatibility, performance-per-watt, and OEM scale as the ARM–x86 contest intensifies through 2025.

search_results.title: Copilot+ PCs expand availability with new AMD and Intel silicon
search_results.snippet: Microsoft confirms Copilot+ PCs, first launched on Arm (Qualcomm Snapdragon X Elite/Plus), are expanding to x86 with AMD Ryzen AI 300 and Intel Core Ultra 200V, with new AI features rolling out to eligible devices starting November 2024. This signals x86 systems will join the AI PC fight into 2025 after Arm’s head start, backed by co-engineering with Intel and AMD and a growing native app base.

search_results.title: Intel vs. Arm: The Microsoft factor
search_results.snippet: JPR notes Copilot+ initially prioritized Qualcomm’s Arm platforms, but Intel’s Lunar Lake (Q3 ’24) hits the 40+ TOPS NPU bar and targets Arm on efficiency; Intel argues Microsoft needs x86 for scale. The outcome will be driven by software support and Copilot+ readiness, pointing to a more balanced Arm–x86 AI PC competition over the next year.

search_results.title: Arm Holdings Aims for Dominance in Windows PC Market
search_results.snippet: Reuters reports Arm CEO Rene Haas expects Arm to exceed 50% of the Windows PC market within five years, citing Microsoft’s stronger Arm tooling and Qualcomm’s Snapdragon X Elite as the vanguard, with other vendors to follow. The push underscores rising pressure on x86 as AI features proliferate across Windows PCs through 2024–2025.

Arm engagement model improvements for st.query: Arm engagement model improvements for startups under Arm Flexible Access programs
Arm engagement model improvements for st.answer: Arm has enhanced its startup engagement model through Flexible Access by expanding the included IP and subsystems, offering zero-cost Entry Tier access via Arm Flexible Access for Startups, and broadening eligibility criteria. The program now adds IP like Cortex-M85 (with Helium and safety kit), Corstone-310 with Ethos-U55, and Mali-G310/C55, while deferring license fees until manufacture. Eligibility has evolved from an initial $5M funding cap (2020) to startups with less than $20M (current FAQ), making it easier for more early-stage companies to prototype on Arm.

search_results.title: Arm Expands Flexible Access with More IP, Subsystems and Technologies
search_results.snippet: Arm details engagement model improvements by expanding Flexible Access with new IP and subsystems—adding Cortex‑M85 (with Helium and a safety package), Corstone‑310 with Ethos‑U55, Mali‑G310 GPU and Mali‑C55 ISP—on top of a package covering 80+ Arm IP. It reinforces the design‑first, license‑at‑tape‑out model and notes early‑stage startups can join at zero cost via Flexible Access for Startups to accelerate lower‑risk AI‑capable SoC prototyping.

search_results.title: Arm Flexible Access Frequently Asked Questions
search_results.snippet: The FAQ clarifies current startup eligibility and benefits: early‑stage startups developing silicon with less than $20M in funding qualify for Arm Flexible Access for Startups and get Entry Tier access (80+ CPU/GPU/system IP, tools, training, support) with license fees only due at manufacture. It outlines the three tiers (Standard, Entry, DesignStart) and confirms the Flexible Access package is reviewed every quarter to add new IP.

search_results.title: Arm extends free access to core designs for startups – Tech Design Forum
search_results.snippet: This report on the launch of Arm Flexible Access for Startups explains the initial engagement model: “early stage” startups with no more than $5M in funding could access Arm Cortex‑A/R/M processors, select Mali GPUs, and other SoC building blocks before licensing, supported by a partnership with Silicon Catalyst. It provides context for how the startup engagement model has since broadened.

Arm cyber security posture for protectin.query: Arm cyber security posture for protecting architecture source and design toolchains
Arm cyber security posture for protectin.answer: Arm’s cybersecurity posture to protect architecture, source code, and design toolchains combines a formal Security Development Lifecycle with hardened enterprise controls and coordinated incident response. Code and cloud console access is tightly governed (MFA, VPN + SSH keys, encryption at rest), development follows living threat models with continuous verification and proactive testing (red teaming and bug bounty), and PSIRT (as a CVE Numbering Authority) coordinates responsible disclosure and mitigations across the ecosystem.

search_results.title: Arm Security Program
search_results.snippet: Arm details an enterprise security program aligned to NIST CSF and ISO 27001 that safeguards codebases and toolchains: strict logical access to systems (MFA, VPN plus SSH keys), encryption of data at rest, a secure development lifecycle with living threat models, coordinated vulnerability disclosure and patching, 24/7 detection and response, and tested business continuity—spanning people, processes, third parties, and cloud environments.

search_results.title: Arm’s Security Development Lifecycle (SDL)
search_results.snippet: Arm embeds security from architecture inception through release via a tailored SDL for hardware, software, and solutions: early threat modeling and security requirements, continuous verification and attack‑oriented testing, documented Security Risk Assessments, and feedback via PSIRT (as a CVE Numbering Authority), with ongoing improvements driven by real‑world findings.

search_results.title: Arm’s Systematic Product Security Approach
search_results.snippet: Arm applies defense‑in‑depth across silicon, firmware, and software, combining architectural security features with SDL, a PSIRT for coordinated disclosure, and proactive testing (internal red team and bug bounty). Standards and community engagement (e.g., TrustedFirmware, PSA Certified) help reduce risk and strengthen security throughout development toolchains and the broader ecosystem.

Arm supplier diversification plans for c.query: Arm supplier diversification plans for cloud compute and EDA licensing resilience
Arm supplier diversification plans for c.answer: Arm is mitigating supplier risk by running EDA workloads on a hybrid, multi‑cloud platform—initially on AWS but architected to be portable and now operating on both AWS and Google Cloud—so projects can be moved between providers. For EDA licensing resilience, Arm is working across the major EDA vendors (Cadence, Synopsys, Siemens/Mentor) and formalizing this through its Arm Total Design ecosystem with pre‑integrated, validated EDA tool flows, broadening vendor coverage and reducing single‑supplier exposure.

search_results.title: Arm's Cloud EDA Success: Two Paths to Greater Value
search_results.snippet: Cadence details how Arm built a hybrid on‑prem/multi‑cloud platform for EDA: starting on AWS Graviton, then making its Cloud Foundation Platform portable to other clouds and now running EDA workloads on both AWS and GCP. Arm can move projects between cloud providers and uses this setup to run Cadence tools (Xcelium, Jasper, Spectre), directly supporting cloud‑compute supplier diversification for EDA.

search_results.title: Arm Total Design for Specialized Infrastructure Computing
search_results.snippet: Arm’s Total Design ecosystem provides pre‑integrated, validated IP and EDA tools from multiple partners (e.g., Cadence, Synopsys), plus design services and foundry support (Intel Foundry Services, Samsung, TSMC). This partner model diversifies critical suppliers around EDA toolchains and manufacturing, improving resilience and reducing reliance on any single vendor.

search_results.title: Arm Moves Production-Level EDA to the Cloud with the Help of AWS
search_results.snippet: Arm announced migrating the majority of its EDA workloads to AWS to cut on‑prem compute, while collaborating with major EDA vendors—Cadence, Mentor (Siemens), and Synopsys—to port and optimize their tools for Arm compute environments. The cross‑vendor EDA support and cloud migration underpin licensing and operational resilience.

Arm measurement framework for ROI on dev.query: Arm measurement framework for ROI on developer ecosystem investments like Kleidi AI
Arm measurement framework for ROI on dev.answer: There isn’t a single Arm-specific ROI framework, but credible industry models exist to measure returns from developer ecosystem investments like Kleidi AI. Use SlashData’s Developer Engagement Value (DEV) to quantify direct and indirect value per developer, and the Linux Foundation’s TODO Group guide to track program-level impact (participation, project health, recruiting, reputation, compliance). For Kleidi, map adoption and performance uplifts reported by Arm to these frameworks to produce ROI estimates.

search_results.title: How to calculate the dollar value and ROI of an onboarded developer.
search_results.snippet: SlashData proposes the Developer Engagement Value (DEV) framework to quantify the total expected value an onboarded developer brings over time—direct (usage) and indirect (influence)—across seven categories (DDV, SSB, PIV, DmIV, DRV, DFV, DCV). Using global survey data, it models developer-segment evolution and links DevRel/marketing/product initiatives to scenario-based changes in developer value, enabling ROI estimation for developer ecosystem investments.

search_results.title: Measuring your open source program's success
search_results.snippet: The Linux Foundation’s TODO Group guide explains how to define ROI and success for open‑source/developer programs by aligning goals with business strategy and tracking metrics like developer participation and influence, project health, external vs. internal contributions, organizational reputation, recruiting/retention, release cadence, and compliance. It recommends baselines, dashboards, and stakeholder buy‑in to demonstrate impact and secure continued investment.

search_results.title: Kleidi – Software-Level AI Acceleration
search_results.snippet: Arm Kleidi integrates optimized AI kernels into popular frameworks (e.g., PyTorch, ExecuTorch, llama.cpp) to deliver out‑of‑the‑box inference performance gains on Arm CPUs without extra developer work. Arm cites concrete uplifts (e.g., 30x faster on‑device audio generation, 20% faster Llama 3.2 1B, 2.5x faster TTFT on Graviton3) and emphasizes ecosystem partnerships and developer enablement—an example of a developer‑ecosystem investment whose adoption and performance gains can be tied to ROI frameworks.

Arm process for prioritizing R&D program.query: Arm process for prioritizing R&D programs given headcount growth and budget limits
Arm process for prioritizing R&D program.answer: Arm prioritizes R&D through a market-led, long-term roadmap process: cross-functional engineering, marketing, and finance teams look multiple years ahead to select a few high-return programs, align them to vertical product families, and set explicit investment and return targets. Recent investor materials show disciplined scaling of engineering headcount (majority in R&D) while managing OpEx, with management emphasizing adequate allocation of R&D resources and balancing new-technology investment (e.g., compute subsystems, Armv9) with profitability.

search_results.title: Arm Holdings plc Annual Report and Consolidated Financial Statements (FYE 31 March 2025)
search_results.snippet: Arm’s strategic report explains operating costs rose primarily due to engineering hiring; average employees increased to 7,676 (from 6,557) as it invests in people to develop AI‑capable CPUs. Management flags that allocating and maintaining adequate R&D resources (personnel and development technology) is essential, with risk management processes in place to monitor this. The report underscores disciplined scaling of headcount and OpEx while growing the base of licenses that drive future royalties.

search_results.title: Arm Business Briefing (SoftBank Group IR) – Q&A, March 21, 2024
search_results.snippet: Arm’s IR describes how it scaled R&D post‑SoftBank—shifting from one CPU family to four market‑focused families—and now targets the right balance between investing in new technology and allowing profitability to come through. To meet AI and compute subsystem demand, Arm hired ~1,000 engineers last year and plans similar hiring in subsequent years, while aiming for revenues to grow faster than costs.

search_results.title: ARM Strategic Report 2015 – Our financial strategy (CFO on investment and R&D portfolio)
search_results.snippet: The CFO outlines Arm’s R&D prioritization process: engineering, marketing and finance teams plan five years ahead to identify development projects that generate the best returns, recognizing that starting a new processor program can take hundreds of engineer‑years. Arm expands R&D capacity (hiring and tools) and ring‑fences investment programs with explicit budgets and targets (e.g., ~£40m added OpEx with a ~$200m revenue target by 2020 for networking/servers/IoT), showing a structured approach to portfolio selection under resource constraints.

Arm China receivables balance, aging pro.query: Arm China receivables balance, aging profile, and collection trends by quarter
Arm China receivables balance, aging pro.answer: Arm discloses receivables quarterly and breaks out related-party exposure, which is largely Arm China. In Q1 FYE25 (quarter ended Jun 30, 2024), gross receivables were $823m (trade $442m; royalty $381m) with allowance for expected credit losses increasing to $19m from $3m at Mar 31, 2024, and PRC revenue was $128m. Arm’s Historical Quarters Datasheet shows related‑party revenue (proxy for Arm China) by quarter trending from $140m (Q1 FYE24) to $162m (Q2), $248m (Q3), $174m (Q4), and $124m (Q1 FYE25), indicating normalization after strong FY24 collections. Reuters notes Arm China historically paid late, with ~24% of FY2023 revenue but ~40% of accounts receivable attributed to China, and $713m collected from Arm China in the most recent fiscal year. A detailed receivables aging schedule by quarter is not published; the higher ECL allowance and disclosures reflect credit/aging risk.

search_results.title: FYE25 Q1 Historical Quarters Datasheet (Arm Investor Relations)
search_results.snippet: Arm’s quarterly Historical Quarters Datasheet lists revenue from related parties (a proxy for Arm China) alongside total revenue: Q1 FYE24 $140m, Q2 $162m, Q3 $248m, Q4 $174m, and Q1 FYE25 $124m. This enables quarter-by-quarter analysis of Arm China’s contribution and collection normalization through FY24–FY25.

search_results.title: Arm: Consolidated Financial Statements (Form 6‑K) — quarter ended Jun 30, 2024
search_results.snippet: The Q1 FYE25 6‑K shows receivables and credit quality: trade receivables $442m and royalty receivables $381m (gross $823m), allowance for expected credit losses rose to $19m from $3m at Mar 31, 2024, and PRC revenue was $128m. Arm expectations for CSS-driven royalty.answer: Arm indicates automotive CSS will begin contributing over the next year: management said multiple auto customers are working on CSS for 2025, with automotive v9/CSS close to launch (licensing deferred to backlog until release), implying royalties to ramp as chips ship. search_results.title: Arm Holdings plc (ARM) Q4 2024 Earnings Call Transcript
search_results.snippet: On the Q4 FY24 call, management said multiple automotive customers are working on CSS for 2025 and that v9 for auto/CSS had not yet been delivered, with related licensing deferred into backlog until launch. search_results.title: Arm Q4 FY 2025: Record Revenue as Armv9 and CSS Ramp Up
search_results.snippet: Analysis of Q4 FY25 highlights royalty expansion from Armv9 and CSS and notes Arm signed its first automotive CSS agreement with a global EV maker. search_results.title: Arm Compute Subsystem Aims to Speed Up Automotive AI Chip Design

The disclosure indicates the revolving facility remained undrawn and that interest on any drawings would reference risk‑free benchmarks (SONIA/SOFR) with an applicable spread, alongside the company’s debt maturity context.

search_results.title: F-1 - SEC.gov
search_results.snippet: Arm’s IPO registration statement (Form F‑1) describes its capital structure and credit arrangements, including revolving credit capacity, how interest on borrowings is benchmarked to SONIA/SOFR plus a margin, and where to find maturity information within the debt and liquidity sections carried forward to subsequent annual reports.

Arm partnerships for advanced packaging.query: Arm partnerships for advanced packaging and 3D integration in upcoming CSS generations
Arm partnerships for advanced packaging.answer: Arm is aligning Neoverse CSS roadmaps with an ecosystem of foundry and design partners via Arm Total Design to enable advanced packaging and 3D integration. Collaborations include Samsung Foundry (2nm GAA and advanced packaging on CSS V3) and engagements with Intel Foundry Services and TSMC, while Arm’s Chiplet Summit guidance highlights foundries leading with new 3D techniques for chiplet physical placement—showing how upcoming CSS generations will be delivered as multi‑die systems.

search_results.title: Arm Total Design for Specialized Infrastructure Computing
search_results.snippet: Arm’s Total Design program builds an ecosystem around Neoverse Compute Subsystems (CSS), giving partners preferential access to CSS alongside pre‑integrated IP, design services, and foundry support. It explicitly lists Intel Foundry Services, Samsung, and TSMC as foundry partners with technology optimized for leading‑edge nodes and advanced packaging, enabling faster delivery of CSS‑based compute chiplets and future multi‑die designs.

search_results.title: Samsung Foundry Partners with Arm, ADTechnology and Rebellions to Develop an Innovative AI CPU Chiplet Platform Ideal for Modern AI Datacenters
search_results.snippet: At OCP Global Summit 2024, Arm announced a collaboration with Samsung Foundry, ADTechnology, and Rebellions on an AI CPU chiplet platform built on Arm Neoverse CSS V3, using Samsung’s 2nm GAA process and advanced packaging. The initiative targets 2–3x efficiency for GenAI workloads and showcases CSS’s alignment with state‑of‑the‑art packaging and multi‑die chiplet architectures.

search_results.title: Engaging Foundries to deliver chiplet based SoCs
search_results.snippet: In a Chiplet Summit presentation, Arm’s Marc Meunier outlined how Arm Total Design accelerates CSS‑based compute chiplets and stressed foundries’ roles: establishing chiplet design flows, validating interoperability, optimizing power/clocking across the package, and leading with new techniques like 3D for physical placement. A case study featured pre‑validated Neoverse V3 CSS with advanced 2nm process and packaging on Samsung Foundry.

Arm updated policies on device-level roy.query: Arm updated policies on device-level royalty audits and enforcement mechanisms
Arm updated policies on device-level roy.answer: Reporting and legal filings indicate Arm has shifted toward a device-level royalty model, seeking royalties based on the end device’s price and requiring direct OEM licenses, rather than only licensing chipmakers. Enforcement relies on standard contractual mechanisms—royalty reporting and audit rights in Arm TLAs that allow independent accountants to review partner records—and, per litigation disclosures, leverage over access to Arm-compliant chips to push OEMs to accept direct licenses.

search_results.title: How Arm aims to squeeze device makers for cash rather than pocket pennies for cores
search_results.snippet: Citing the Financial Times, this report explains Arm’s revised model: royalties based on the value of the end device (e.g., a smartphone) and direct OEM licensing. Under this approach, chipmakers would use Arm cores under development licenses while device makers pay Arm royalties tied to device ASPs—moving the royalty base from chip to device and tightening control via OEM agreements.

search_results.title: Case 1:22-cv-01146-MN Document 19 (Qualcomm counterclaim vs. Arm)
search_results.snippet: Qualcomm’s counterclaim alleges Arm told OEMs they must accept new direct licenses with royalties based on OEM product sales to obtain Arm‑compliant chips after 2024/2025, and threatened to license competitors if they refused. The filing outlines Arm’s enforcement posture around device-level royalties and direct OEM licensing as leverage.

search_results.title: This Technology License Agreement (TLA) between ARM Limited and Hynix (audit clause)
search_results.snippet: Arm’s TLA terms include royalty reporting and explicit audit rights: the licensee must keep detailed records (e.g., ASP, units) and Arm may appoint independent chartered accountants to audit books to verify units shipped, ASP/fair market value, and royalties due. These standard clauses show how Arm enforces royalty compliance via record-keeping and audits.

Arm expected timing and scope of any sha.answer: Arm has not provided any timing or scope for share repurchase or dividend announcements. The company explicitly states it does not intend to pay a dividend at this time, and its IPO prospectus says it intends to retain earnings and does not currently plan to pay dividends. There is no public disclosure of a share repurchase authorization in Arm’s investor materials or SEC filings, so no timing or scope has been announced.

search_results.snippet: Arm’s investor FAQ answers “Does Arm pay a dividend?” with: “No, Arm does not intend to pay a dividend at this time.” The FAQs and other IR sections contain no mention of a buyback program, indicating no timing or scope has been announced.

search_results.snippet: In the Dividend Policy section of the final prospectus, Arm states it intends to retain any earnings for use in the business and does not currently intend to pay dividends on its ordinary shares/ADSs; under UK law, dividends require distributable reserves—no timing or scope is provided.

report:
# Arm Holdings (ARM) — Next-Day Outlook and Equity Research Update

## 1) Investment Recommendation Summary
- Stance: NEUTRAL
- Rating: HOLD
- Next market day view: Range-bound trade; we expect ARM to move broadly in line with the NASDAQ in a ±2% band absent new company-specific headlines. Near-term upside appears capped by valuation and licensing volatility, while downside is cushioned by visible H2 royalty growth from Armv9/CSS and hyperscaler deployments.

## 2) Executive Summary
Arm’s structural monetization engine is accelerating: Armv9 transition, rising Compute Subsystems (CSS) adoption with materially higher royalty rates, and increasing data center mix (Neoverse at hyperscalers) are all lifting royalties per device and mix quality [3][4][6][12][14][24][34]. Q1 FYE26 delivered a second consecutive $1B+ quarter with royalty revenue up 25% YoY, and management signaled a softer 1H followed by 10–15% sequential growth in 2H, implying mid-to-high-teens to roughly 20% FY26 revenue growth potential depending on license deal timing [10][1][2]. 

However, full-year guidance was withheld due to tariff uncertainty, licensing remains lumpy, and customer concentration and China exposure are non-trivial [1][2][7][8][9][20][27]. Margins are best-in-class (non-GAAP GM ~98%; OM ~39–45%) and tax credits keep the effective tax rate in the mid-teens, but valuation already discounts substantial growth and execution [17][18][19][28][29][30][31]. 

We maintain HOLD/NEUTRAL: Fundamentals are strong, but risk/reward into the next day and near term looks balanced with limited multiple expansion catalysts until additional CSS/design-win disclosures or a clearer tariff backdrop emerge.

## 3) Company Overview
- Business model: Designs and licenses CPU, GPU, and system IP based on the Arm architecture; monetizes via up-front licenses and per-chip royalties. Also offers developer tools and CSS platforms to accelerate customer chip development.
- Revenue streams: License and Other; Royalty. End markets span Client/mobile & PC, Infrastructure/data center, Automotive, and IoT/embedded.
- Scale/financials: FY2025 revenue $4.007B; FY2025 GAAP net income $792M; market cap ~$167B (as of 2025-11-05).
- Competitive positioning: Arm is the default smartphone architecture and is gaining in cloud servers and AI PCs; key competitors include x86 ecosystems (Intel/AMD) and RISC-V across embedded and edge.

## 4) Key Findings by Category

### A) Next-Market-Day View
- Setup: No new guidance post Q1 FYE26; CFO indicated a softer 1H, H2 reacceleration, and licensing volatility, which tempers near-term directional conviction [1][2][7][8][9]. 
- Trade call: Expect ARM to be range-bound and trade with broader semis/AI peers as investors await evidence of H2 royalty acceleration and additional CSS wins. 

### B) Revenue and Mix Outlook
- Near-term cadence: Q1 FYE26 revenue was $1.053B; Q2 guided to $1.01–$1.11B [29][32]. Management highlighted 10–15% sequential growth in 2H, implying mid-to-high-teens to ~20% FY26 growth potential depending on license timing [1][2]. 
- Royalties: Up 25% YoY in Q1 FYE26, driven by Armv9 adoption and more CSS-based chips [10]. Prior quarters showed similar strength (Q2 FY25 royalty +23% YoY; Q3 FY25 +23% YoY), with smartphone royalties up 30–40% YoY despite flat units due to higher value per device [6][28][5][33].
- Data center mix: Infrastructure royalties are now slightly over 10% of mix (cloud about a third of that), with estimates for cloud/networking to rise toward 15–20% of royalties as hyperscaler deployments ramp [12][14]. CSS is expected to drive a mid-single-digit share of total royalties in FY25 and a double-digit share in FY26, with about half of CSS tied to infrastructure [12].
- IoT: Signs of stabilization and recovery emerged in Q3 FY25 after a period of weakness [28][8].

### C) Royalty Rates and CSS Uplift
- Royalty rates: CSS designs typically carry 10%+ royalty rates vs ~5% for Armv9 and ~2.5–3% for Armv8, meaning CSS roughly doubles per-chip royalty vs baseline v9 [3][4]. 
- Smartphone monetization: Smartphone royalties rose ~30–40% YoY in recent quarters despite flat units, underscoring uplift in value per device from v9 and CSS [5][6][33].
- PC vs smartphone: AI PC CPU royalties are expected to be ~10% of CPU ASP vs ~4–5% for v9 smartphone APs, implying higher per-unit royalties in PC, though TAM visibility is less certain [15][4][16].

### D) Data Center and Hyperscalers (Neoverse)
- Penetration: ARM expects close to 50% of compute shipped to top hyperscalers in 2025 to be Arm-based; AWS Graviton, Google Axion, Microsoft Cobalt are ramping, and NVIDIA’s Grace CPUs (paired with Blackwell) add to Arm CPU footprint in GenAI servers [34]. Management commentary suggests server chips based on Neoverse nearing 50% share at top hyperscalers in 2025 [24].
- Mix/royalty impact: Data center chips tend to use more IP and carry higher aggregate royalty rates, supporting a rising data center share of total royalties [13].

### E) Automotive (Zena CSS)
- Pipeline traction: Launch of Zena CSS and the first automotive CSS design win, with engagements across over one-third of global OEMs; initial deployments should support higher-royalty CSS monetization as ramps begin [10][5].

### F) Margins, Opex, and Tax
- Gross margin: Non-GAAP GM consistently ~97–98% irrespective of license/royalty mix, underscoring mix-insensitive unit economics [17][18][19].
- Operating margin: Recent non-GAAP OM ranged from 39% (Q1 FYE26) to 45% (Q3 FYE25) [29][28].
- Tax: R&D credits have driven low effective tax rates (Q4 FYE25 GAAP tax benefit; non-GAAP ETR ~14%; Q1 FYE26 non-GAAP ETR ~15%), supporting net income [30][31].
- SBC/opex: Management gave quarterly opex guidance (Q2 non-GAAP opex ~ $655M) but no full-year SBC outlook; investment is accelerating [32].

### G) Licensing, RPO, and Sovereign/National AI
- Licensing volatility: Management widened guidance due to the unpredictable timing of large license deals; some could slip across quarters or fiscal years [7][8][9].
- RPO: ~$2.23B with ~25% recognized over the next 12 months, providing partial visibility but not a quarter-by-quarter layout [22].
- Sovereign AI: Malaysia to pay $250M over 10 years for seven high-end Arm blueprints to seed domestic AI chip design; disclosures indicate license upside from national programs but uncertain royalty tails [25][5].

### H) Customer Concentration, Litigation, and Qualcomm
- Concentration: In FY2025, the largest customer was 17% of revenue; next two at 11% each (fourth at 10%); top four at 49% — implying top three ~39% [20].
- Qualcomm status: Qualcomm indicated Arm withdrew its breach notice and has no current plan to terminate the architecture license agreement, reducing a key overhang; Arm still seeks a new trial on other questions [23]. 
- Litigation: Ongoing matters disclosed with outcome uncertainty; no quantified FY impact [21].

### I) China and Geopolitics
- Exposure: PRC was ~18.7% of FY2025 revenue [27]. Arm reports US trade restrictions had an “isolated impact” and describes robust IP-protection programs to mitigate leakage [26].
- Guidance withheld: Management declined FY26 guidance due to tariff uncertainty; called out a softer 1H and H2 sequential growth [1][2].

## 5) Investment Thesis

### Bull Case
- Royalty rate expansion: The transition from Armv8 to v9 and the ramp of CSS (10%+ royalties) significantly lifts value capture per chip across smartphones, data center, and auto, compounding royalty growth even in flattish unit environments [3][4][5][6][10][11].
- Hyperscaler momentum: Arm CPUs are increasingly foundational to cloud and GenAI infrastructure, with top hyperscalers deploying Arm-based CPUs and Grace-Blackwell systems, supporting a higher data center royalty mix and rates [34][24][13][12][14].
- Margin durability: Near-98% non-GAAP GM provides operating leverage; non-GAAP OM in the high-30s to mid-40s is sustainable with scale, while R&D tax credits anchor a mid-teens effective tax rate [17][18][19][28][29][30][31].

### Bear Case
- Policy risk and visibility: Full-year FY26 guidance withheld due to tariff uncertainty; licensing remains lumpy and large-deal timing is hard to forecast, which can whipsaw quarterly results and sentiment [1][2][7][8][9][22].
- Concentration and ecosystem risks: Heavy reliance on a handful of customers and material PRC exposure create outsized idiosyncratic risk (pricing, volumes, enforcement, remittances) [20][27][26].
- Competitive pressure: x86 in PCs and servers and the RISC-V ecosystem across embedded/edge could cap long-term rate expansion or displace some sockets; PC TAM for AI remains uncertain even if per-unit rates are higher [15].

## 6) Key Risks
- Geopolitics/tariffs and export controls affecting China and global customers (guidance withheld due to tariff uncertainty) [1][2].
- License deal timing and volatility (RPO conversion only partially visible; large deals may slip across periods) [7][8][9][22].
- Customer and geography concentration (top-three ~39% of revenue; PRC ~18.7%) [20][27].
- Litigation/regulatory outcomes (Qualcomm/Nuvia overhang improved but not fully extinguished) [23][21].
- Competitive disruption (RISC-V adoption, x86 push in PCs/servers; Android softness risk to smartphone royalty dollars) [15].
- Macro and device demand cycles impacting unit volumes even as rates rise.

## 7) Conclusion and Outlook
- Next-day call: NEUTRAL; expect ARM to trade in line with the broader market in a ±2% band given a lack of incremental catalysts today. We would be buyers on pullbacks into H2 if CSS/design-win news flow accelerates or tariff headwinds abate.
- FY2026 operating outlook: We model FY2026 revenue in a ~$4.7–$4.9B range (mid-to-high-teens to ~20% YoY), assuming a softer 1H and 10–15% sequential growth in 2H as implied by management commentary and ongoing royalty mix uplift; non-GAAP OM in the ~39–42% range, with GM ~98% and ETR ~14–15% supported by R&D credits [1][2][10][17][18][19][28][29][30][31].
- Strategic milestones to watch:
  - Additional CSS licenses and production ramps across client, infrastructure, and automotive; CSS share of royalties moving to double digits in FY26 [12][11].
  - Hyperscaler deployments (Axion, Cobalt, Graviton, Grace-Blackwell) translating into rising data center royalty share [34][24][14].
  - Sovereign AI/national programs (e.g., Malaysia) adding to license wins, with potential future royalty tails [25][5].
- Investment view: HOLD. Arm’s structural drivers are intact and strengthening, but today’s valuation already embeds much of the H2 growth and CSS/data center upside; we await clearer visibility on tariff dynamics, license timing, and additional CSS design-win disclosures before upgrading.
